Despite being an FPS game, this was very playable on controller. Since my computer sucks at running... well... anything, I decided to give this a try on my Steam Deck. I was surprised at how well the gameplay flowed on controller, even though I may have had some issues every now and then. Overall, my experience has been positive. I love the uniqueness of the story, and the wide array of weapons to choose from and enemies to fight. The soundtrack is definitely a banger, especially during bossfights. I did have a few controller-related issues though. First and foremost -- and probably the biggest issue for me -- is the whiplash. I could not get it to work for the life of me. I ended up spending hours searching through Reddit posts to figure out how it works, only to give up and rebind it to some other awkward button. The tutorial stated it's "LB + RB", but that did not work whatsoever. I ended up rebinding it to a button on the D-Pad, which is really awkward to hit because you have to let go of your left joystick (the one that controls the player's movement) to press it. I've barely used the whiplash since I've unlocked it. My second issue happened during the Leviathan bossfight. When you play on controller, the game enables an auto-aim feature that snaps your crosshair (but not your camera) to enemies that are already not too far from your crosshair. I love this feature, as it makes this game actually possible on controller. During the Leviathan bossfight, it would not snap to the boss. That's fine; the thing's big as fuck, so I don't need an auto-aim... especially when the boss is at the side. When I try to shoot the boss while it's doing the spinny-thing with its tail, my crosshair snaps to the whiplash orbs on each side of the arena. This makes me miss the boss 99% of the time during this attack, which frustrated me because it wasn't my fault. My final issue is the settings menu. It's laid out pretty decently, and looks clean too. The issue is I can't navigate it at all using a controller. I could edit the first few options, but every option below refused to be highlighted. Irritatingly, I had to use touchscreen to change them. I think Ultrakill shouldn't be deserving of a Steam Deck verified rating yet, not because it's bad (hell, I fucking love this game), but because of the issues I've had. If other games aren't verified because you "need to use touchscreen to navigate a launcher" or some other GUI, then I think Ultrakill should be demoted to playable too. This hasn't ruined my experience, but has just made it a little bit more irritating. Ultrakill is still really fun though. I'm addicted to the cyber grind, especially with the soundtrack that comes with it. The guest artists did a great work. I also love the customisability of the cyber grind. Importing your own textures is a great idea, and I spent ages tinkering with to make my cyber grind arena look cool. I've yet to beat Act 3, but what I've experienced so far has been really enjoyable. Go play Ultrakill. It's an experience to be had on your own, so don't spoil yourself and play it immediately. Trust me, you'll become addicted like me.

I heavily love this game's combat and movement system, it's one of the best one's that I've ever played but, that's as much praise I'll give it. I only play this game for that reason only because of it's use of religion towards the christian church. If you don't really don't care all that much about it then go for it and buy the game but, if you're into the lore and you're a christian, it'll most likely bug you. It's heavy use of religious poses, almost seeming like it's mocking them, and having St. Gabriel become this sort of fallen angel doesn't sit right with me. Especially the Idol's which protects certain enemy's, in hell btw, being a exact reference towards The Immaculate Virgin Mary holding baby Jesus. Call me weird but I don't care, but when I saw that, I couldn't take it open me to destroy it and progressing forward. Over all, the story of Ultrakill seems very blasphemous, which can ruin the game for some people. I would only recommend the game only for it's movement and it's combat system, but not it's story. Though, all of that being said, I mean no hate towards the developers of the game, and I also love the music as well, it's one heck of a banger to listen to, it's just the story that bugs me; that's just my opinion though.

I have been on iRacing for 10 years coming up and I have to say it is one of the best decisions I made in terms of gaming. This has turned into a complete hobby for 8 years now. While there are other simulators available which are great and bring to the table better graphics and a few other features, iRacing is the full package. While cost is definitely the first thing that was on my mind when I started, I personally feel that it has never been easier to get into cost-wise. Unless you see yourself rising through the ranks quickly, you really won't be likely to purchase any additional content for the first 3-6 months. This would also be my recommendation. Multiplayer is the reason to be on iRacing. There is no better sim out there when it comes to multiplayer. That is because the community and iRacing police this. The protest system will boot those making the experience tough on other competitors. As you race among the same people, you will begin to respect and be respected by your peers. (For instance, my team will go against the same team in endurance races a couple times a year). While racing can be unforgiving of mistakes, understanding that mistakes happen is part of racing. If you dont desire racing against real people, iRacing probably won't be for you. However, you will miss out on true grit racing and testing yourself against equally skilled racers. I am a big advocate for iRacing and I feel that this review is overdue considering I only connected steam 5 years ago (Hours should be doubled). Give iRacing a chance and enjoy the community it has to offer.

Best online racing. Yes, it is expensive compared to other sims but you don't have to purchase all the cars and tracks right away. There is a ton of series, cars and tracks. You start at Rookie level. There are many series, cars and tracks that come free with Rookie Level to pick from. A person can continue to play at Rookie Level as long as they want, even after you earn your other class licenses. However, after working your way out of Rookie and D class and earning your C license, most people will probably want to start racing in C series races. That's when you will really need to start thinking about purchasing an additional car and additional tracks for the higher series you will be running in. There are also Time Trial events and AI racing, if you don't want to race against real people online.

I have actually hundreds of hours in this game, it's not counting as I usually start it directly from the iRacing UI. This game is slowly dying. You have to pay for subscription periodically, and there is only a few categories that are 100% free. MX Cup for example, with Mazda RX-5, will make you lose your mind as this car is totally unbalanced and unpredictable. Some times you lose 20 minutes between joining a race session and qualifying, and in the final laps of the race the car will suddenly spin out in a way not even god can save it. If you think this is because I'm a bad driver, well, these words came for a professional Nascar driver that also run away from this category. There are other categories like GR Cup which sometimes brings paid tracks. If you decide to invest on this category, be aware that you will fight the devil for ever. People often will take you out of the race by commiting mistakes or even intentionally. You can raise a protest, there is a cool down time after the race to make you forget and move on but if you really want to proceed and protest be aware they will just send you a standard response saying they didnt see nothing intentional in the incident. There are many other sim racing games you can play for much less, you might experience even worse situation but at least you are not paying a subscription and 20 dollars every time you need to buy a new track.

If you enjoy driving and want to improve your skills, this is the game to play. If you view this game as a money sink then walk away now you will never understand this review. This game is a privilege to play, having monthly subscriptions means that the service runs smoothly. As far as the prices for cars and tracks my advice is don't try to learn every type or racing or level up your licenses all at the same time. What types of vehicles do you really want to race? Find that vehicle and see if there are current race series going on, not all cars have events running. Then look at the track schedule for the event this will show you what tracks the event will race at, so you can clearly see what you would need to participate in all events for that car for the season. If you want to race all types this can get very expensive very fast, and it will be harder to get skillful in any one discipline. I would much rather spent $15 to be able to experience a world class race track, than have a fast food burger!

I'm going to start with what a lot of people have issues with, and that's the price. iRacing is a great game, the pricing, however, is extortionate. Now you might be thinking that $20/month isn't so bad, and you would be right, it isn't. The problem is, that £8.99/month only gets you access to the Rookie series. Thereafter, you have to pay $11.95 per car and $14.95 per track. You do not need all of the cars and tracks but, using the GT3 series as an example, so for me to participate in this seasons GT3 series, I would need to at minimum, buy one qualifying car for $11.95 and 12 tracks at $14.95 each ($179.40). And that's just for one series, if you want to participate in more than one, add another $11.95 for the car and $14.95 for tracks you haven't purchased yet. As you can see, it does get expensive, however, you can spread the cost out as it's one track per week for each series. With that said, despite the fact that it pisses me off you need BOTH a subscription AND need to buy cars and tracks seperately, I would still recommend iRacing - though, only if you enjoy multiplayer. iRacing is by far the best multiplayer racing sim available. Races run at set times every hour and I've found there are always people racing. You'll have to ignore the Steam statistics as the majority of people use iRacing outside of Steam. You have a safety rating and iRating which promotes clean racing and you will be matched with racers with similar skill level to you. It's great for multiplayer racing but as above, it's just unfortunate you have to pay for literally everything outside of Rookies at $11.95 and $14.95 a pop. It gets cheaper long term as you no longer need to keep buying cars and tracks because you've already gone bankrupt by purchasing them all. It is an extremely fun game though... Edit: It's actually worse than above... iRacing charge tax at checkout instead of including it into the display price. So your $11.95 car becomes $14.34 and $14.95 tracks become $17.94. As if paying for a subscription and paying for the content isn't extortionate enough, they slap you in the face at the end with tax. It's still a great game but ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ hell....

Phenomenal Real Time Strategy game. I originally started playing in the 2000s when it first came out on Windows XP. It's incredible to finally be able to play again. The remastered game is even better than the original with more civilizations, game play options, higher population limit, much improved opponent AI, and much better graphics. The year was 2000. I was on vacation, far from home, visiting my father. Every morning, the anticipation would build as we drove to my aunt's house, where I'd spend the day while he worked. But what made those days truly unforgettable was the thrill of immersing myself in Age of Empires II. At 6:00 am, I'd dash to my cousins' room, boot up their computer, and slide in that iconic game CD. The next several hours would fly by as I built empires, strategized battles, and navigated the richly detailed world of medieval history. Age of Empires II wasn't just a game; it was a gateway to a world where I could control knights, castles, and civilizations, all while learning about history in the most entertaining way possible. Replayability was endless. Every match offered new challenges, whether I was perfecting my strategy against the AI or conquering the campaign. Even after spending entire days engrossed, I'd come back the next morning with the same excitement. It wasn’t just the gameplay—it was the music, the atmosphere, and the joy of mastering the mechanics that made it an unforgettable part of my childhood. Age of Empires II isn't just a game for me; it's a cherished memory of simpler times, of family, and of endless possibilities. Over two decades later, it remains a masterpiece that holds a special place in my heart. If you've never played it, you're missing out on one of the most timeless and rewarding gaming experiences ever created.

I grew up playing AOE I and while AOE II is similar enough, it took me a bit to learn about all the new changes that came with it. Thankfully, it didn't take long for me to enjoy huge amount of campaigns you get for this game and that's before I got all the DLC. If you're into multiplayer, there's a lot there as well with loads of maps and civilizations to choose from. The barrier to entry for multiplayer is high, but an advanced tutorial can help you learn proper build orders and unit counters. Over the years, they've updated this game a ton. Everything looks less pixelated than the HD edition and the animations have been improved, especially when buildings get destroyed. The civs still get updated to make them more viable in multiplayer and while not all of it works, it's commendable that they're still trying even up to the date of this review. The accessibility and options are also great, though playing with a controller is still pretty limited compared to keyboard and mouse. The only big issues I have are that the pathing AI is still not great as units tend to stick to each other or get stuck against objects while in tight spots. And while the AI is better than before, there are instances where you can easily cheese it with a well placed castle or using ships to fire at melee units as they flail around. Finally, as mentioned before, the multiplayer is fun, but also very daunting if you want to get into the meta as there's 20 years worth of experienced knowledge that a newbie will have to know to ensure they don't get decimated. Overall though, it's fun to play whether you go solo or multi. The two are practically different games where one is a chill history lesson and the other is a fast-paced war. And now that the first three DLC are free, there's way more content than ever. Give it a shot.

This is a game where I feel there is a button missing between approve or disapprove. After a long thought I simply cannot recommend this game despite nostalgic feelings and good old funky theme. I am a big fan of the franchise and the game did deliver some of that feeling... but it also made me sure that I was indeed the targeted audience upon which to profit from. So, kudos to the marketing team of the game: well done, you got me, as you probably got others. Regarding the game, after the initial spark and a smile here and there, the game quickly becomes a tedious walk between very limited amount of locations. It looks like a modern cheap ripoff of the Monkey Island 1 where the designer team was simply too lazy to invest time and effort for any kind of creativity. The "puzzles" are so lame that they would insult the intelligence of an average monkey (pun indented). The addition of the hint book simply adds salt to the wound. I understand that the times have changed dear devs, and that an average gamer needs a quest marker, compass, visual and hearing aid as well as a 10 hour tutorial and a crutch to move forward but IF YOU ARE CREATING A GAME TARGETED FOR THE OLD HAGS AND VETERANS IN THEIR 40ties or 50ties DO NOT INSULT THEM. Thank you.

I wholeheartedly recommend this game, even for people without any nostalgia for adventure games. Personally, I have fond memories of playing The Secret of Monkey Island as a 7-year-old in the attic of a friend’s place. We never made it far, but the images of the lookout, the town, the circus and the cardboard pirate wheel are burnt in my brain forever. When I got older, adventure games could never capture my interest again. I was mostly frustrated with puzzles that needed a specific solution while the space of theoretically possible solutions was infinite. In the end, I came around after watching the noclip documentary on Return to Monkey Island’s development. The developers really put all their love into this game, and it shows. I love the non-conformist graphics style. It contributes something new and doesn’t only wallow in pixel nostalgia. I love all the variety of dialogue options, delivering multiple punchlines at once. Often the puzzles themselves are like a dialogue with the developers, tempting them by trying outrageous things and smiling when it turns out to be something that they considered. I love all the meta components, also the ending. Shutting the theme park down made me surprisingly emotional about leaving this world. And in the end, I’m really thankful for the modernizations compared to the original. Looking in the hint book from time to time didn’t break the immersion as does looking up hints on the internet or starting a vicious cycle of angrily trying out all theoretical combinations. And I’m unsure if I just imagined it, but did I get a recap when I came back to the game after a week?

The story is great, I loved it. The puzzles are good fun. I was really disappointed by the graphics, of course a matter of personal taste. Every time I moved on to another scene I could not help myself from thinking: why on earth would they spoil such an amazing game with so lousy graphics. So look at the screenshots, if you can live with them go ahead and play the game, it's great fun.

Wow, just wow! Do you know how when you watch an M. Night Shyamalan movie and then the ending is so absolutely horrible that it doesn't even matter what the rest of the movie was about. That is this game! As a life long Monkey Islander completionist Ron Gilbert couldn't even do his fans who have supported him with their time and money the service of completing his game. Terrible form. Literally don't waste your time unless you want to be disappointed. I've never been as let down by a game designer as I have by Ron, and I played all of Richard Garriott's Ultima games! Couldn't at least someone at Devolver (my favorite game studio) have talked some sense into the man. I am very not happy and neither are my friends who watched along with me. DO NOT BUY!

This game summarizes the best saga ever created for graphic adventures and one of the best games in history. It's a different adventure, but at the same time is the same as always. It's a game made for everyone, old and new. This is the kind of game you want to play after a long day at work. It's the game you want to play with your little brother after homework or on holidays. It's a game that puts all other big budget games to shame. It is passion, dedication and effort for the craft. It is a game for all the mighty pirates. It is a masterpiece. Thanks you, Ron Gilbert. Este juego resume la mejor saga jamás creada de aventuras gráficas y uno de los mejores juegos de la historia. Es una aventura diferente, pero el mismo tiempo es la misma de siempre. Es un juego hecho para todos, viejos y nuevos. Este es el tipo de juego al que quieres jugar después de un largo día de trabajo. Es el juego que quieres jugar con tu hermano pequeño después de los deberes o durante las vacaciones. Es un juego que avergüenza a todos los demás juegos de gran presupuesto. Es pasión por el trabajo, dedicación y esfuerzo. Es un juego para todos los piratas. Es una obra maestra. Gracias, Ron Gilbert.

I hope Ron Gilbert gets blacklisted and never is allowed anywhere near a game engine again. EDIT: Went back and gave it a second chance. I'm 114 laugh-free minutes in. This is really painful. It's nostalgia bait with callbacks that aren't enjoyable. The art is uglier than the staff of Kotaku. Every returning voice actor sounds like they don't want to be there, as every line comes off with a feeling of exhaustion. The new actors are 90% female and have that air of hipster smugness due to being in a le heckin' retro oldschool classic. Most of the puzzles are just running back and forth between two locations for events to trigger, and any that require any actual problem solving are incredibly obvious. If a book has been written on how to dig up the corpse of a video game series and then defile it with no lubricants, the development team has memorized it. There are no redeeming qualities about this game. It's THAT FUCKING BAD. I haven't played Tales (I have it on my account because I impulsively buy games on sale), but there's no way it can be this bad. This feels spiteful (which makes sense, because Ron Gilbert always hated the fact that Curse was the best game, and it retconned his stupid ending from 2), like The Last Jedi of adventure games. Escape was a bad game, but it at least felt like they WANTED to do something good (and it had hits as well as its more frequent misses). This feels like an angry letter to fans for enjoying Curse. If you bought this game, I'm sorry to hear it. I hope you're within the refund window. If you haven't bought this game, DON'T. You deserve what you get if you don't heed my warning. Fuck it. Comments are open. Have fun.

I recommend this game because at its core it is a good game and if you are a monkey island fan, of course you should play it. As a long time monkey island fan though I was disappointed especially after having high expectations after Thimbleweed Park which is an INCREDIBLE game (70 hours playing TP, 7 playing RMI). This review will share those feelings in case other people might feel the same way. For the good, it is still monkey island and the overall cast and feel is what you would generally want from Monkey Island and an adventure game. I appreciate the art style as an attempt to do something new and different. There are no puzzles that really stood out or that I had a lot of fun with. I got to a point late in the game where I realized the solution to a puzzle was so obvious and required so much backtracking to pick up a particular item that I just stopped playing - I was not motivated to do what the game wanted me to do. This game is also in the tough situation of wanting to acknowledge its roots but also look ahead. The result however is that revisiting locations from past games is simply not interesting or exciting. You’re on Monkey Island for about five minutes and that’s it. This is also how I felt at many of the new locations in the game - there was not the sense of meaningful exploration and investment in an area that you had in past games. The result is you hop from place to place doing minor puzzles here and there. Another minor gripe I have is the relationship between Guybrush and Elaine is very lovey-dovey. This is a woman who would give Guybrush hell even after they got together so it’s weird to see her fawning over him, and it became another thing that didn’t feel quite right. Maybe I need to play it again but ultimately a disappointing experience given the high expectations I had and the long-time hope of a new Ron Gilbert monkey island game.

Let me preface this with - the art style is fine. It's appealing once you get past your preconceptions and it looks beautiful in motion. OK, now that THAT'S out of the way - I don't know if the recent world has just worn down Gilbert and his collaborators. But this is utterly depressing. Guybrush is irredeemable, He's a legitimate sociopath in this. And crow is never once on the menu. He gets forgiven offhand after basically sentencing a beloved character to hellish torture and stealing his possessions. I can't endorse a Monkey Island game that makes me despise the main character the entire time I'm playing. A few moments of self-awareness are instantly washed over with narrative dissonance in a way that undercuts any empathy for the characters. Guybrush just SUCKS as a person in this game. He's awful. I had very high hopes and I absolutely love 1, 2, 3, and the TellTale series. I don't hate 4, I just... well, it's its own thing. But this is just a bad game propped up by Gen X nostalgia and a drought of this style. It's not good. It's not abhorrent, but it's not good.

If you're a classic point and click fan, avoid this game. The first games used verbs, and you really had to think and move the mouse around to solve puzzles. They were engaging and fun. The third game introduced a wheel with three action options. It was dumbed down but still challenging and fun. You had to move the mouse around to find interactive items on the screen. Some were really well hidden or unexpected. You still had to think. This... you just hold tab to see the interactive bits. Move the mouse there and a big pop up will tell you what it is and what you can do, before you've even had a chance to think about what it might be. It tells you which mouse button to click to do what thing. It's absolutely infantile, utterly dumbed down. A monkey could get through this game by spamming tab and clicking everything. What a shame, what a pointless end to a franchise that started so well.

I can’t downvote this game. Because the art in the end is beautiful and I really enjoyed the nostalgia and meeting the characters again. The story was cute and I loved the new characters too. However, it is painfuly short and doesn’t give any closure. Honestly… it feels unfinished, like half of the actual story was cut out. A bit spoilery warning: Whatever you do, do NOT stepp through THAT door at the end of the volcano-puzzle! It will ruin everything.
A must for nostalgic players

It is a well executed adventure game let down by its story. There is still plenty to like about the game. The puzzles are for the most part good and don't venture into moon logic territory. I also appreciated that there is a in-game guide that you can refer to if you are stuck. My biggest gripe with the game, as previously mentioned, is the writing. It leans heavily on the previous games and the referential material gets old rather quickly. The ending is, more or less, Ron Gilbert jumping out from behind the curtain and blowing a raspberry at you. There are still lots of funny moments and it is always nice to see some of the characters again that we first encountered in Monkey Island 1. All in all I have quite mixed feelings about 'Return to Monkey Island'. Overall I would still recommend it, but maybe don't pay full price or you might be disappointed.

I'm a lifelong Monkey Island fan and was SOOO excited to hear that some original team members were coming back to make this. But I shouldn't have been. It's just not good. ART - This is good. I had no complaints here. It's charming! PUZZLES - They were good! Satisfying, challenging, and balanced. They start a little overly easy for someone experienced at point-and-clicks like this, but I figured that was by design, so newcomers to the series could jump in since it was getting a lot of hype. The pacing is odd but fine. DESIGN - A little empty. Gone are the days of combining random things or showing items to NPCs to get unique lines or jokes. Most things have only 1 or 2 possible ways to interact, and a lot of the maps and scenes are just empty. VOICE ACTING - Fine. Some sound a little out of character but having Dominic Armato makes it all OK to me. He's wonderful as always. STORY - Waste of time. It was self-indulgent, pretentious, and soulless. The game feels unfinished. They explain in a post-game letter that this was essentially a mid-life crisis work slash series farewell and it's meant to be disappointing and hollow-- but if you don't know how to write an ending, just admit it. I used this game to introduce Monkey Island to someone new to the series and fully regret it. It's just a disingenuous and bitter-feeling approach to the series that leaves (by design) a sour and tired taste in your mouth. Imagine you launched a new Pokemon game and the first line was, "Welcome to the world of Pokemon. Did you know your parents will die someday? Here's your stupid Pikachu I guess."
Awesome game!

I played all Monkey Island games several times. Did I liked this one? Yes! Is this better than the original Monkey Island 3, the "Curse of Monkey Island"? No, it's different. Even if Ron Gilbert did not work on "Curse of Monkey Island", that game is still amazing nowadays. "Return to Monkey Island" is an hommage to the saga, a third and closing chapter to the original Monkey Island 1 and 2. The art direction is nice and the jokes are still there, but I disliked few things: - It's pretty easy, probably the easiest of the serie. I finished it in just 6 hours. - The atmosphere and musics are too calm and not as expressive as "Curse of Monkey Island". - There are no big happening within the story or stressful puzzle where timing is crucial for example. - I could not find the rubber chicken and the pulley...!? - There is not a single monkey in the game...

The Monkey Island series is arguably the best Adventure Game "series" of all time. This latest game sees the return of series creator Ron Gilbert, and is as good if not better than the original installments. There are tons of quality of life improvements in this sequel such as being able to highlight the interactive portions of the environment, having an in-game "to do" list that updates itself, a streamlined "action button" interface, and even a hint book. I don't know if it's because I completed other games in this series recently, but the puzzles this time around were very clever but also very fair. I found myself rarely resorting to the hints. I HIGHLY recommend this game, but I would also suggest playing the first two or three games in the series first for maximum enjoyment. 5 Stars. I look forward to playing these games with my son one day.

I have mixed feelings about this game. The two writers have a good grasp on the kind of characters that should populate the world of Monkey Island, and indeed -if you're a fan of the series- you'll find your most beloved ones here just like you remember them, with a lot of the newcomers being funny and charming as well (LeChuck's crew stands out in this regard). The overarching plot, however, is another matter. There's quite a few minor plot points that go nowhere, and the overall story in general ends... not as unexpectedly as one would've hoped. Until the ending though, it's a decent enough plot, not too far off from the other games. The dialogue is solid too, doesn't reach the heights of the first three but it never sinks too low either. In this department the voice actors delivered: LeChuck's new one did a fine job, Guybrush's is as good as ever and kudos to Murray's for knocking it outta the park. The problems with the game lie elsewhere, namely: the art. It's better in motion than what you've seen in the screenshots, but it's still a far cry from how the previous chapters handled it. It's a pity, because the idea behind some locations are interesting (like Terror Island), and it makes you wonder how they would've been with a better style. For better or for worse, Guybrush is the worst design-wise, none of the other characters are as ugly. Another problem with the game is its gameplay. Due to how the interface is structured it's way, way too easy, even on its hardest difficulty. The new interface also limits the possibilities of funny dialogue and interactions the previous games offered. It really makes it less fun than what it could've been. So, why am I giving it a positive evaluation? Because I'm a long-time fan of the saga and I never thought I'd see another Monkey Island by Ron Gilbert, namely the one that would finally "reveal" the Secret. On top of that, the fact that he didn't de-canonize all the other games after the second like he originally planned, but instead kept his new one in continuity with them and even paid homage to them (save for a huge, unexplained retcon that however brought back a beloved character) makes for an even bigger surprise, because it goes against most if not all of what he had planned for his third Monkey Island. He even kept the romance between Guybrush and Elaine, ain't that sweet. I hate loose ends, I don't like retcons and, few exceptions aside, this is a game that concludes the whole saga without disregarding what came before, made by its original author. It's not like I hoped it would be, it's not perfect or even excellent, but I'm still glad it exists.

I am really liking the game so far it is just as fun as the others and the addition of hints is much appreciated as I don't need a paper guide like I had for the older ones. Only things I am not crazy about is the art style for the characters kinda wished it was like curse of monkey island or escape. And am not really keen on whoever is voicing Lechuck I know the original actor retired but still couldn't he have come out of retirement just to voice Lechuck one more time if he was passionate about his character you would think he would right anyway just didn't find the replacement very scary or commanding as the original actor other than that I am enjoying the game. It makes me a bit sad and I miss the other games considering melee island looks so run down now sad to see it that way. Highly recommend.

I enjoyed playing this game so much that I'll start playing the first two again as soon as I'm done writing this review. The music and art style caught me off-guard. They're such a perfect combination of new and old. I don't want to cast shade on any other MI games, but I certainly preferred the style of this one. Maybe that's because the humour, heart, and message are also impeccable: exactly the kind I remember from playing/watching my brother play these games when I was a child/teenager. It did not overstay its welcome, being a little shorter than I remember the others being. While I could easily complain that I would have liked it to be longer (because, honestly, I would), I'm actually happy with the length: it means I don't have to build up the will to play it again. I can just dive straight in, which I will be doing, right after I'm done with Secret and 2. Tldr; I loved it, and if you liked the originals, I think you will, too. Devs, tysm for making this.
Loved this game. Not too difficult but also not very easy. :)

I can only give the thumbs-up here with certain reservations. The game doesn't come close to the memories of earlier games, but I can't say for sure whether these memories have become more and more beautiful over time. Some puzzles where you had to repeat something several times to succeed (rubbing grease into a porthole) seemed a bit annoying to me in terms of puzzle design, but the rest was basically well done. The hint book is a useful addition if you want to make steady progress and not get stuck on obstacles for too long. From a narrative point of view, however, the biggest oddity of the entire project is the ending. It comes so suddenly and leaves so many questions unanswered that you get the impression that the production ran out of money.

[i]Return to Monkey Island[/i] is a good, well, return to the [i]Monkey Island[/i] series. I've played through the first few games, didn't play through all of the fourth (that early 3D was really rough), and have only played the first of the Telltale series, so bear that in mind. Almost all the voice actors are back doing what they do best (Dominic Armato remains amazing as Guybrush), and the soundtrack stays true to what you'd expect. I, like many others, was shocked when I first saw the new artstyle, but I soon grew accustomed to it as I played. Puzzles aren't quite as difficult as other games. There were only a couple I had much difficulty with, but part of that can be explained by the fact that if you can't use an item on another one, it just won't let you, and I don't recall any "Moon Logic" puzzles. There's also a hint book in the game if you get stuck, which appears to be there because someone who truly wants the answer without figuring it out would just look up a walkthrough. With all that being said... it's not perfect. Insult sword fighting, a staple of the franchise, is almost nonexistent. There are also trivia cards to test your knowledge of the game series, but they're randomly scattered around and have to respawn (and will only do so if you've been answering them), and if you want to get the achievement for answering them all, you're going to end up walking back and forth and loading saves to get them. I got maybe 25 of them in my first playthrough. Finally, a lot, and I mean [i]a lot[/i] of people didn't like the ending, so ye be forewarned.
Ask me about LOOM!
Very much recommended for all the old gamers of Lucasfilm/LucasArts. New players will also enjoy the adventure!

I got a bit of dejavu. What more can I say, i've never played the game before, it's clearly not the same, yet it picks up a lot of things that made the original game great when i was a kid. As an older person who played the original when released, this game is great, i'm just about to go back in and complete for the first time. A strong recommendation from me for those that played the original. :) Enjoy the nostalgia wave whilst playing a good game. ;)

I've been a fan since the original Monkey Island game and was very hype for this game when it was announced. Return to Monkey Island had plenty of references to the older games but the magic was no longer there. The story, jokes and pace couldn't be delivered and live up the expectations for fans of the series.

The Monkey Island games were my introduction to point-and-click adventures and will always have a special place in my heart. From the start, 'Return to Monkey Island' gives the exact same vibe. It feels both like playing another chapter in the Monkey Island series, and at the same time the new aspects make it feel better tailored for modern point-and-click gaming. Personally, I find the art style just beautiful too. Hits right in the nostalgia. The refresher dialogue you get in 'Return to Monkey Island' when coming back to the game after a couple of days of not playing, asking if you remember where you left off and giving you the option to get a brief reminder of the story so far and your current objectives, or just get right back into the game, is such a neat feature. More games should be doing this, please.

As a big Monkey Island fan I was very happy this even came out, and I enjoyed it immensely. The art style grew on me very quickly, the music was as good as its ever been, and the puzzles had good logic, and the clever improvements to the point and click adventure game formula were great! Some mixed feelings about some stuff but this is already a classic, really hoping for more adventure games coming out!

There are tons of nice things to say, but the most important is the vibe that the game was made with heart by someone who truly cares about their characters. A super sweet letter and a game made with love. On a bittersweet note, I'd add that the message really hit the mark.
I loved it! It's fun, the right amount of time and challenge! I liked the ending and reliving the old memories! Worth buying =)
A great set of comic puzzles in keeping with the original series

The Monkey Island series is a pillar of PC gaming history. This (final?) addition is the culmination of years of perfecting the art of the point-and-click adventure. The return to 2D did for this series what it did for Metroidvania-style games, in that it was a choice that revived the spirit of the franchise. The art style is perfect for this series. I'm on my second playthrough of this. I did the story mode first and am now on hard mode. Both are incredibly enjoyable, though I do recommend hard mode for its extended gameplay and additional puzzles. There's an option in the settings to turn on Writer's Mode, which adds tons of additional dialogue, that I insist every player turns on. The ending is bittersweet and fun. I've played all but the first game, and I think I might have to go back and play that one now too.

Played though first two games just to the the grasp of the game. First two games were amazing even with the old graphics. This one appeared to be shallow and woke. Couldn't continue after and hour and a half...

The game was fun, not great fun until the completely uninspired ending. It wasn't that it didn't make any sense (it really doesn't have to in MI), but it was just a big anticlimax. No revealings of any secrets and not even a good joke to finish the hunt with something that gives a feel of accomplishment. The ending is basically: "We didn't really come up with what the secret is, so you just chased it for nothing". Monkey Island was always a story driven game, but sadly a story without an ending is a bad story. I would have thought ron gilbert would have come up with a great idea after all these years, but obviously he just jumped at the chance to do a sequel without having any inspiration to do a sequel.

Absolutely and utterly loved the game! Took me back about 30 years to when I was playing the very first Monkey Island - happy days back then...it was lovely to see all the old crew once again and to be completely puzzled by the ending as usual :-) just buy this game, it won't let you down!

Wonderful, so many great puzzles with relatively few instances of moon logic that the genre is infamous for. They compensate for a difficulty spike in the third act with a fantastically paced hint book. An excellent finale to the series, but established fans of the series will get the most out of its ending.

The internet had a meltdown about the art style, and i'll admit I didn't love the look from the initial screenshots of the game. However, as soon as I started playing and heard the familiar voices and felt the excitement of a new Monkey Island, that all went away. The game mechanics/controls were great and I especially liked the walking speed which felt just right. The first half of the game felt a bit easy, almost like I was just living out the story instead of solving puzzles. It was always clear exactly what to do next, but I was still having fun. The second half was more challenging but still on the easy side. There were a few times I wandered around not knowing what to do, only for the answer to be facepalmingly simple. The end was a bit underwhelming, but I understand why they did it. Was anything ever going to live up to the lofty expectations we all had for what we might find? Probably not. No matter what, everyone has their own idea of what it "should" be. I had a ton of fun, and I cried at the end. I hope the adventure continues, but if it doesn't, what a beautiful, hilarious and memorable ride this series has been. I think we're having a real moment here.

If you've enjoyed previous Monkey Island games, you will love this one just as much. Very nostalgic! I wish I had chosen to start with the harder version because now I'm missing out on some fun puzzles, but I guess I'll just have to play it twice!
I'll keep this review as succinct and at the same as positive as it can possibly be: It's a worthy sequel

Borderline not recommended. I've played through all of the Monkey Island games and this was the weakest entry yet. I can tell the team wanted to do it justice but it just seems like they're out of ideas. Some of the classic humour is there and shines through but very seldom. The new characters are very dull and the old characters are executed less effectively than in the past. There's nothing offensive or necessarily objectionable, just very underwhelming so a long-time fan. For context, my favourite was MI2, followed by MI1 and MI3. MI4 was ok, then Tales was subpar and then this was below that. I was hoping that the involvement on Ron Gilbert would elevate the end product but I can't say it seems to have made much difference.

It may look different, but still the same feeling, same fun jokes and even the same voice after over 20 years since my first monkey island game.

I loved the original Monkey Island as a kid, and replayed some of them over the years. I just finished this game, and I feel like they missed the mark. It was mildly fun, mostly due to nostalgia. I really wanted to like this game. The art style seems like flash animations, which I assume makes it cheaper and more accessible. It's colorful but not great to look at. The game pacing feels alright. Although you must do a lot of back and forth, you can get pretty much anywhere quickly, which is good. Some puzzles are decent, but for other, in-game clues are too sparse, and I was forced to use the hint book. It's great there IS a hint book, but it also feels like a cheap way to guide players through illogical puzzles with unexpected solutions. There should be more suggestive direction in the dialogue in these cases. Speaking of dialogue, I thought the voice acting was great, and the dialogue was good. Maybe I was burnt out by the end, but the ending puzzles were not well done. The ending is a weird joke that nobody gets. The letter from the developers somewhat justifies the 'has-been' approach to Guybrush Threepwood's adventures, and makes me think they were just too busy and underfunded to give Guybrush the adventure he deserves.
Relive the glory days of Monkey Island by finding the secret.
Short game but brings back memories

This one is great! A worthy successor to the series. The art style might look off-putting at first but it is handeled and animated really well. 30 minutes into the game and you will probably learn to appreciate that. The puzzles are actually fair, not to easy but not completely bonkers logic defying bullshit. It might take the fanservice a bit too far, especially with regards to the first game but that didn't bother me. Speaking of which, it really leans heavily towards the very first game in terms of inspiration. This becomes obvious from the very start as the scrapbook that tells the story so far dedicates 3 pages towards the first game and one page each for the other games. I just wasn't sure on how to feel about the ending at first as it was a bit abrupt and left a lot of things unanswered, but thinking about it for a long time and the true secret of monkey island (yep, they actually reveal it this time) it all makes sense to me, but due to spoilers this is where I will stop talking about this. Obviously after 30 years of teasing not everyone is gonna be happy with how the franchise is coming to an (possible?) end but at the end of the day every player has to judge that for themself. To sum it up, it's brilliant to get a game that is easily offering as much content as the old monkey island games, while having a production value that feels contemporary all for like half the price of a blockbuster game back then. Also it's is much much better than Timbleweed Park.

Boy this brings me back... i first played Monkey island in 1991, my english werent that good. I was only 5 years old. I was already playing some Maniac Mansion and then i saw this game. What a feeling...what a music...facing an evil ghost spirit pirate LeChuck. Arrrrgggh :P The game of Return to Monkey Island was really really very good. Connected so much about the past. Really well done guys! I played it with my father and i saw him with tears. Haha i was so pissed about the T-Shirt again being the secret but i guess its just fair for the story and franchise. I will be really disappointed if this will be really the last because we witnessed a small Easter Egg about the lost treasure of Mire Island... i wonder what will happen there...and what happened also to LeChuck. Thank you again Mr. Gilbert :)

Recommended, with a caveat, AND ONLY for die-hard Monkey Island fans who loved the first two games. The caveat? This is nowhere near as good as the first two classic games for many different reasons, explained very well by the creators within the notes of the game. It actually kind of made me sad at times, returning to Melee Island and ultimately Monkey Island, during the course of the game, looking around and seeing just how much things have changed. It's like they say, you can never go back home. Neighbors have moved or died, businesses have closed or been remodeled to the point of being unrecognizable, the atmosphere is... different. So, if that's what you're looking for, go for it. I mostly enjoyed it. But now, I really just want to go back and play the first two games again to scratch the itch that this game can't even reach.
Well Guybrush, i payed more than 20 bucks for this.

[h1]One GLARING issue aside, a good entry into the series.[/h1] TLDR: The artsyle is atrocious, the game's good otherwise. I was introduced to the Monkey Island series through means of Curse of Monkey Island, third entry into the series and a phenomenal game. Later I tried the original MI2 with DOSBox support, but found it less than ideal. The remakes of MI1+2 were good games, Escape from Monkey Island and Tales from Monkey Island repulsed me though. Return to Monkey Island... tbh? I really, really loathe the artstyle. It looks as if some of the worst animation ideas of the last two decades were blended into this atrocious artstyle. Thankfully the story and the humour are good enough to be enjoyable, with a lot of references/cameo's and so forth to prior games. Unfortunately there's a limited amount of things you can do in game with the different items you collect, which is a little sad. But with the series creator involved that's something you can look beyond hopefully. [b]To buy or not to buy?[/b] TBH, aside from the grotesque artstyle and the weak beginning it is a good game. Mostly a trip down memory lane for MI fans, but with enough for those not familiar with the series to enjoy it too. But you ought to look closely at the screenshots on Steam and videos on youtube or twitch to see if you can stomach the art style of the game before buying it. Even with a discount, that's one glaring issue with the game that can make/break/ruin the experience.

I would recommend this game to anyone who is looking for beautiful story driven game, with an amazing soundtrack, and countless hours worth of good game play. A fantastic narrative experience unlike anything I've played before! Full of twists, turns, and surprises that manage to maintain curiosity and intrigue throughout the run. This game also manages to masterfully encourage exploration and experimentation, weaving your unique set of decisions into it's own unique, but cohesive, experience! This game has had a lasting impact on me, and I'm looking forward to playing this again and seeing what other stories I can uncover! What are the things that I like about this game? [list] [*]Fantastic presentation! From the beginning, the fully voice-acted narration, the pencil-drawn scenes, and the subtle score all create an incredible atmosphere which definitely got me invested in the story from the get-go. In particular, I wasn't entirely sure about the voice-acted narration at first, since I tend to be the sort of person to try and read through dialogue as fast as possible, but I would say that the narration is some of the best parts of this game. It really helps build the characters and the various scenes you find yourself in. [*]Unravelling the story is very fun and enjoyable! You'll start off the game with many questions, and the game's pacing does a great job at "breadcrumbing" answers to you. As you have more conversations and encounters, you'll start building up your own understanding of the world and what's happening in it. I really enjoy that it feels quite open-ended also! There's a lot of room for interpretation at every step. [*]Content-dense and lots of replay value! This game can be as short or as long as you'd like it to be, which I think is great! I finished my first run in about 3 hours, which felt like a good pace for me, but I know there are many other routes I could have explored. I get the impression that there's WAY more to see in this game than what I experienced, and I'm really looking forward to digging in more. [/list] Who would I recommend this game to? [list] [*]People who enjoy narrative-focused games [*]People who like games with multiple endings (and enjoy 100%-ing them!) [*]People who enjoy visual-novels, or people who are lukewarm on visual novels but willing to give exactly one a try (this is your sign!) [*]People who can immerse themselves in the morality of decision-making in games [*]People who enjoy exploration [*]People who have a small amount of time to game per day [/list] Who would I NOT recommend this game to? [list] [*]People who prefer action-packed games [*]People who dislike backtracking [*]People who prefer to be scared senseless (this game barely contains horror elements) [*]People who want to experience gameplay beyond dialogue choices [/list]

It's best to go into it blind as to formulate your own opinions before hearing the thoughts of others. I cannot overstate how much this game means to me and how in love I am with it. A must play for people who appreciate a good story and have the patience to listen to hours of dialogue.

No BS- hands down absolutely one of the best games I have ever played. It's funny, emotional, thought provoking- you feel every sort of emotion when playing! Now I'm not one to write reviews so the fact that I AM writing one for this game means something. I- like a good chunk of people who know of Slay the Princess- found out about the game through Markiplier; and thank god I did! Before I even finished watching the first episode of his playthrough, I immediately opened steam and bought the game. That's how captivated I was. Slay the Princess is a wonderful work of art, and it's insane how the whole game was basically made by 6 people! The 2 game devs- Tony Howard-Arias and Abby Howard- who are also the only writers and artist for the WHOLE game. The 2 VAs- Jonathan Sims and Nichole Goodnight- who both showcase an absolutely incredible display of range! And the composer for the games music score- Brandon Boone-, along with the games sound designer- Phil Michalski- who we have to thank for the games fantastic sound palette. I love love love LOVE this game, and I'm purposely not saying anything else about the gameplay as- like other reviews have mentioned- it's best when you go in knowing nothing :P If you've made it this far into my review then I hope I've given you enough food for thought. PLEASE PLAY THIS AMAZING GAME!!!

It has long been my belief that art exists, fundamentally, to make you feel things. This game is art. It is perhaps one of the most ambitious artistic masterpiece I have ever seen in the video game medium. Why? Because it doesn't strive to evoke just one feeling. It runs the gamut and succeeds masterfully. It manipulates you, and even though you know that it is doing it, it still pulls it off. This is not your standard visual novel. It genuinely barely deserves the label. There is no particularly intricate plot. The only time you get long, tedious info dumps is if you go looking for them and constantly choose every conversation option that isn't a decision. This game is really just a series of conversations with yourself and two other people. And then? And then you have to *decide*. What do you believe? Who do you trust? What morals do you value? I'll try to be vague because this is genuinely a game that will be better the first time without spoilers, but everything after this paragraph might potentially be a little spoilery. Before I lose some of you though, make sure you check the game's options. You can turn off certain sound effects if you think they'll be too visceral. This game is a complex web of choices that all matter. From an initial three-ish decisions the game branches into at least 10 primary routes that are all radically different. The slightest deviation in your conversation choices, even apparently innocuous ones, can put you somewhere completely different. And those routes can branch into others too. And all of the paths make sense. Very, very rarely, if ever, will you look at the list of choices and think "I don't want to do any of these things. There's a reasonable choice missing." (A full game usually involves five self-contained loops. On plays 2-5 the game will block off routes you have taken in the previous loops. Fear not, once you get the credit screen all choices will again be available. Or you can just start a new game.) The voice acting is both spot on and a critical component of conveying the emotions and trustworthiness of the characters. This game is more than simply a story. It's an examination of psychology and moral choices in a very real, visceral, and grounded manner...at least as grounded as a fantasy story can be. This is an experience everyone needs to have.

For the longest time i didn't really have a way to contribute to the "what game will you pick if you could wipe your memory off of it and have a fresh start again" topics. Now, i think i do. This one. I'll be honest, i envy you, the person reading this, if you never played or saw this game yet. For all 30 hours up until now, i was hooked on trying every option, every route. To listen, to laugh, to anguish, to get a gut wrenched sideways. But slowly i'm reaching the end. Sure i could just reset my progress and go at it again, but it won't change that i know the outcomes. Board reset will not change anything. Maybe i'll return later, when i forget. When the time to meet Princess is again. Join me. The Princess is worth it. Her voices, our voices. Our actions, her reactions, our reactions, her actions. Slaying or not. Now pushing off the melancholy a little bit, objectively speaking this game is awesome, even for a person like me that doesn't have much interest in visual novels. Great voice acting, incredibly variety of choices ranging from sickly sweet down to morbidly cruel and everything in between, with outcomes from satisfying to ones you would prefer to alt+f4 then to experience them. You will feel happy, sad, distraught, in awe, in pain. And by the time it is done - you will long for the spark that you experienced, but the only way for you to do so is to forget. And Princess will still be here, when the time comes to meet again. Definitely worth it. And remember, most of all, regardless of what you choose or not. This is a love story.

I'm not into visual novels or princess stories, so I initially dismissed this game as something I definitely wouldn't enjoy, without looking too much into it. But after seeing it pop up everywhere, over and over, I finally decided to give it a try. Best decision ever. This is one of those incredible experiences that sticks with you and influences your perspective on life in one way or another. Maybe it will stir up old memories you didn’t even realize you still carried. It’s a beautiful and horrifying game that will leave you desperately sad but also laughing out loud. I’m still amazed at how incredibly well it’s written and how it almost feels like it’s reading your mind as you play. Combined with its expressive, stunning art and flawless sound design, it’s easily the most profound experience I’ve ever had in a video game. I think I’ve seen it all by now, but without a doubt, I’ll find myself on that path in the woods again someday.

I gotta say, it's been quite some time since I last treated myself to a horror game that isn't free, first time in a while since I spent cash on a horror game, looked pretty interesting, and this, I gotta say, is one of the best experiences in horror I've had in a while, the game was worth every cent, I loved it, it's been a while since I got decently scared, it was refreshing feeling intimidated and cowering away in fear and trying to save resources by keeping fighting the beast to a minimum and just running if possible, I loved and still do love this game, and I want more of it, I desperately crave it, but something like this, I don't think I'll be able to find a continuation or a decent formula that a similar game can replicate or do in their own, and that saddens me, but I'm glad I at least have this one game, that has done what they did in this Amnesia game, and for that I gotta say, it's one of the best horror games I've played in a long time, I'm a huge fan of what they did in this game, and I wouldn't mind spending more cash if there ever was continuation of this, or a game had something like this with more places to explore, thank you to everyone who made this, I can't thank them enough for this masterpiece, this is the only time I'll ever see a 70$ price tag as justifiable if the price tag got slapped onto this game, but thankfully they didn't, the saints at Frictional only put it 25$, even if they may not always hit the mark, you guys are awesome, and I love this game.

Among Frictional's best work, has the best gameplay out of all of their games by far. I especially love how reactive the world is to your actions and the short term and long term consequences and dangers you'll face based on your actions. The monster is absolutely terrifying in appearance with this fear only being amplified as it destroys everything in its path in an attempt to hunt you down. Leaving the relative "safety" of your hiding place and observing the wreckage left in the wake of the monsters endeavours to find you is almost as terrifying as if it were to actually succeed in its efforts. Having to navigate slowly through areas with debris, or move objects out of the way to proceed forward adds to this building tension whenever the monster is not in play and hiding in the walls as during these periods of downtime, said monster is actively listening for you, waiting in anticipation. The monsters behaviour, the reactive world and the large collection of game modifiers and random generation keeps the game fresh and keeps it scary where other horror titles would begin to falter. Easily a 10/10 game for me that I'll continue to play even after completing multiple playthroughs and 100%ing the game. TLDR; French people are absolutely terrifying.

It was really a scary experience down there in the bunker. I played it on normal because I could not handle the stress when I started this dangerous journey. The game requires you to plan your excursions to the tunnels well ahead, or you get into some big trouble. You have to manage your resources wisely, otherwise you may have to endure some tough moments in the darkness ... and probably die. It teaches you some self control to resist the urge to run :) In summary, this game greatly achieves to create a scary atmosphere in a grim and musty bunker during WW I and keeps you on maximum alert throughout the game. I hope I will some day be brave enough to challenge myself on a higher difficulty, but for now my pulse has to settle a bit.

Uniquely brisk-pace survival horror. You lose some of the depths of immersion as the gameplay really demands you to think mechanically if you want to make progress and do it well so if you're making that sacrifice you have to make sure the gameplay carries its own aesthetic. I'd say this succeeds at that and largely outshines all the previous FG titles. Of course we're all nostalgic for the older games, but they were really leaning on presentation over substance back then. If that's what you like, fine, but I loved the frantic and involved feeling of this one. It's all pedal to the metal all the time and then ends right as you start getting the hang of it. For one, that makes it a perfect package, no bloat. But also this sense of only beginning to really grasp how good you can get at the very end of the game serves as the enticement for the new game+. Some randomized key items, alterations to the monster and boom. Now it's a challenge-run type of game. I was satisfied with what I got simply playing through once on normal, but this is clever. This game shows off a matured design-sense which is exciting for future projects.

[b]8.0 out of 10[/b] [b]Pros:[/b] Will scare the sh** out of you, can be very challenging, lots of replayability (rogue-lite elements), good game design, stellar sound design, and pure unadulterated horror fun. [b]Cons:[/b] Graphics are solid but could be better, not everyone will like the rogue-lite elements or the setting, some wonky bugs and physics, unfair in places, questionable AI at times, and fairly short game (can be finished for the first time in about 4 to 6 hours). [b]Verdict:[/b] Amnesia The Bunker is a somewhat shorter game in a fairly contained map, but d@mn if the developers did not make masterful use of every inch of it's underground complex! This is legitimately one of the scariest games I've played in a while - every moment of it is engaging and intense. And the level/sound design makes this a very immersive nightmare to experience. There are only a few games I would not recommend you play with a headset on if you have a heart condition, and this is one of them. The sound design is stellar and this game will make sure to take every opportunity to startle you like a mofo and leave you white knuckled as you creep along in the dark hearing things clawing behind the was or whispering in your ears. No game is perfect, and this one has some little bugs - but Amnesia: The Bunker proves you really don't need fancy graphics, giant AAA teams, or even a big budget to design what is probably the best horror title on steam in a long time. It is also not a very demanding title and can be had very cheap many times thru-out the year - especially during sales where it gets as low as $12.49. If you are looking for a inexpensive horror masterpiece to scare the hell out of you for a few hours at a time (or a solution for your constipation problem), then look no further.

This game is a lot lighter on the story compared to the other Amnesia games but still a decent and interesting one regardless, and it has the most fun and engaging game play in the series. This game can be as easy or as difficult as you want it to be. After your initial play through (if you choose to play through again) the game let's you tweak everything from the monsters behaviour, to how long your torch burns. The randomisation of every resource in this game can make it pretty exciting but dreadful at the same time when you understand how screwed you are. And if you wanna go a step further, I recommend the survival game play overhaul mod in the workshop. I think Frictional Games have made one of the best survival horror games with this one, even more so with the updates since it released. If you're on the fence with this game, just... believe the hype.

I found myself often doing sprints to safety rather than skulking about because I knew that I could outrun it or at least delay it.

One of the best games from the Amnesia series. Procedurally generated maps would have made this the best monster hunter game ever created but despite this there is still incredible replay ability with all of the various options for a "New Game" such as monster tweaking, item tweaking and basically anything you could think of; it runs the gamut. Slight criticism on the ending. No spoilers, but it's very "arcade" like. You wold be surprised how many games fall into this trap. It's almost as if the devs completely focused 99.99% of their greatest work on the game, and that very small 0.01% at the very end goes against what the entire game was made for. It's such a minor gripe that it wouldn't take away any recommendation from me for others to play this masterpiece.
Good game, damn scary. A bit short, but I enjoyed my time with it.

It's a good attempt to update Amnesia but it's not big enough and is too fast paced to lean into the play your way style it implies in the opening. This is still a find the object to progress the critical path game, just now with RNG added and setpieces cut back on. You're still going to get the usual bs you'd associate with an Amnesia game too, light elements run out at absurd rates, there's an arbitrary storage limit and stuff despawns between loads. As a result, there's a point in the first hour or so where you've figured out if the RNG is screwing or blessing you where all tension just snaps. It becomes a game about either snappy walks through lit environments or crawls through low light ones and not much else. Once you find another "locked door" that requires another item in an unsignposted location that you once again have to comb the map for and you feel that sigh of frustration, you've experienced everything the game has to offer. Because it doesn't seem to really evolve from that point in any meaningful way.

Amnesia: The Bunker is a 2023 survival horror game by Frictional Games. It's World War I, and you're a French soldier stuck in a ruined underground bunker together with something hostile. Like most games by this developer, this is a first-person horror game with a lot of physics interactions. Many of the game world's items can be picked up, thrown or broken. Doors and cabinets, likewise, feel like they have actual weight and have to be pulled open. It's something that makes the game world feel notably interactive and gives the gameplay some unique flavor. Another trademark of Frictional Games is that their games are very good at creating a tense atmosphere where you often feel powerless. Many of their past games don't have combat at all, and although Amnesia: The Bunker has guns and grenades, they can't be relied on forever. The sound design is also extremely immersive - these games are basically worth playing for the sound and music alone. The dark ambient background music helps you sink deep into a suffocating mood of paranoia and darkness. The main thing that sets Amnesia: The Bunker apart from previous Frictional Games' titles is that it has a stronger focus on gameplay and replayability than lore. It could be likened to a horror sandbox with a semi-open environment and many elements which are randomized on each playthrough. Some key items are always found in the same locations, giving a consistent logic to the overall level progression and allowing the player to plan ahead. But other than that - items and codes are new on each playthrough, and the monster in particular can be highly unpredictable. Like in Alien: Isolation, this game has an unique "stalker" enemy that is hellbent on staying on your tail and showing up at various inopportune times. This monster moves behind walls and is attracted by noise yet avoids light. It's possible to fuel the bunker's old generator to make areas lit for a while, but this simply adds another layer of tension to the gameplay. Do you want to use a limited fuel resource to give yourself temporary (and relative) safety, or brave the darkness alone? The level design is definitely one of the highlights of the game. It's intuitive yet also tells a story. There's a reason for why everything is as messed up as it is, and you'll slowly discover it during the game through short cutscenes and logs. Each sub-area feels unique and has its own feel to it, which helps the game stay interesting all the way through as you progress through it. The game isn't very long, but as mentioned, it's geared for replayability. My first playthrough took about 7 hours on Normal. I then did a second playthrough on Hard, which lasted 2.5 hours. Understanding the level layouts and having a grip on the game's mechanics definitely made a big difference for survivability. As you gain more information, you will be able to tackle harder and harder challenges... at least, if you're feeling up to it. I even watched a playthrough on "max difficulty", which is when you push the difficulty sliders all the way past the game's official toughest difficulty, limiting yourself to a very small inventory, no ability to save, minimal resources and ultra-aggressive stalker. The tactics on this mode are quite impressive, and I even got to wondering: would it be possible to do win streaks in Amnesia: The Bunker on higher difficulties, much like people do streaking in other challenging games with randomized elements like The Binding of Isaac or Slay the Spire? Based on everything I've learnt, I'm inclined to say that the game might be a bit too unpolished for that. Yes, although impressive in a lot of respects, it does have some bugs. For example, I got two crashes after putting the game window out of focus for some time during bathroom breaks. The physics can also do some wonky stuff sometimes, and considering this is a game where physics objects create sound which the stalker can use to find the player, well... you can see how that could lead to a disaster. I've seen some strange enemy-related bugs as well. So, although it's an interesting idea, I'm not sure you can actually beat the game consistently on the most extreme settings. I wouldn't mind to be proven wrong, though! Subjectively, I found Amnesia: The Dark Descent scarier, but Amnesia: The Bunker isn't close behind in this regard. It's a very intense horror title with fairly intricate gameplay mechanics. It's not without its frustrating moments, but understanding how it works can be quite rewarding too. It's definitely worth trying out if this kind of gameplay seems appealing and/or you liked Frictional Games' past titles.

Who would have thought Frictional would deliver a smaller scale, immersive sim twist on Alien: Isolation as the latest entry in their flagship, up-until-now-primarily-narrative-horror franchise? It’s not what I would have guessed, but given the somewhat lukewarm reception to the prior two entries I’m not surprised they chose to mix things up. And by all accounts it appears to have been a pretty good move for them. As far as immersive sim design philosophy goes (ie. multiple ways to approach situations, reactive gameplay elements, etc.) these can often be found in horror-adjacent games, but for various reasons pure horror tends more towards rigidity. The Bunker on the other hand largely ignores those constraints, trading curated scares for an omnipresent invincible creature that prowls the tunnels as it waits for a reason to emerge. You have some options to keep it at bay, but they are limited; your best bet is to stay quiet, but of course that isn’t always viable. Needless to say, it can get tense. Like, REALLY tense. This is amplified by the fact that you have a limited supply of fuel to keep the bunker’s meager lighting active (and thus deter the creature), so if you want some semblance of safety you’ll need to continually push further outwards in search of supplies and the items you need to escape. Naturally you also have limited inventory space, so you’ll need to weigh your options carefully before each expedition. When you don’t have the benefit of the lights you’ll need to rely on your mechanical flashlight for guidance, which requires periodic cranking to recharge - and yes, this will alert your monster pal if he’s nearby. In that sense, the core of the gameplay hasn’t actually changed that much from previous entries; stealth and flight-over-fight are still major design pillars. You just have a lot more tools at your disposal for progressing this time around and the levels are designed with a more sandbox approach in mind. In regards to the level design, I was admittedly a bit skeptical of how interesting a game set entirely in a bunker could look after seeing the first announcement. This was not an issue though, as while it may not have the most striking art direction, everything felt appropriate for the setting and the game is short enough that the environments don’t overstay their welcome. This was aided by the great sound design as well, particularly for the creature and the sounds of war on the surface. Given Alien: Isolation is one of my favourite horror games, I wasn’t surprised that I really enjoyed The Bunker. Besides the gameplay advances it still has a lot of the classic Amnesia feel via the scattered notes and overall plotline, as well as some clever setpiece scares that don’t involve your ill-tempered bunker-mate. Also, for as much as I liked Isolation, this game benefits from being a much more compact experience. It even leans into this by providing various customization options and randomized elements that make the prospect of a second playthrough a lot less daunting than another twenty hours of hide and seek with a xenomorph. I’ll be interested to see where Frictional takes the series next. I could certainly go for another title in this vein, but I suspect they might have other plans. Whatever the case, I’ll probably be there for it - after finally getting around to playing the second and third entries for myself, hopefully.
