This is an amazing game! One of my Top 3 now I was worried it will not hook me as other games, but it overcame my expectations. The setting is well thought out and immersive, mechanics of going through the bunker are very ominous and makes you scared on every corner. That is if you play on settings the game recommends you. I saw many people playing on high gamma due to low vision, which made me wonder why would people completely bypass the whole premise of the game. In low gamma (the recommended one) you barely see into the darkness and without a light you are basically running around as chicken. There is the Amnesia blue filter tho so you still get some vision. At the end of the game i put the gamma a bit up so i dont need to put it on my pc and it felt like cheating. From barely seeing into the end of the hall i was able to see the bottle that would be in darkness perfectly. So i lowered it again to continue my immersion. The game's motto about trying and it may work is true. Like you can be the maniac and throw grenades like an idiot and it work eventually. I heard people complaining about the flashlight you get that its garbage and how its useless. It is sometimes, but it is a point of game - game of sounds and distractions. It's literally Cat & mouse situation in the bunker. You must be careful what you are doing. But for me it was never massive hassle. Itps not like everytime you crank it the mosnter appears near you, so don't worry. Better than the lighter, to be honest. I want to adress the setting as well, because the writers really nailed it. It really hit like "we are in WW1 frontlines and no, it was not nice times". The sadness, anguish, depression, insanity. All that in every note i found was just like a french chef's kiss. Henri is really well written protagonist, who is not out of place, who did mistakes previously and he strongly regrets them. In short - a great representation of ww1 soldier. There are some nitpicks i have with the game (SPOILERS): [spoiler] in Roman tunnels when i got into the area, i was a bit scared about the Touissant guy and how it will go. I was prepared for everything. The problem was just one - One bullet. That's all you need against him. Into the head. I will go to Shellshock mode to see if he needs even more but it ruined it a bit, ngl. If he would just hum his rhymes and then still shoot his shotgun normally it would be perfect. Cause he feels he is drunk, rather than insane. But yea, if the man point was making him human, then it was done right. It just bothers me cause the whole area looks like its prepared for massive sneak section when i needed just one bullet. But i think it may be for the Shellshock playthrough so i will see.[/spoiler] [spoiler] The Monster sometimes felt... dumb. Idk if its programmed like that but the Stalker likes to hit lot of random stuff around him. Even explosive barrels... on his own. So it was sometimes easy him doing something dumb like that and just running back home. But hey, i played on normal difficulty so it may i guess depend on difficulty itself [/spoiler] [spoiler]The ending was a bit confusing of what I am suppose to do, but it didnt took a long time for me to understand it [/spoiler] Overall, the game is awesome and a masterpiece of horror. I would be so happy if Amnesia would go by this direction quite more - the surviving horror with guns and managing resources. I will try in the future the Shellshock mode and potentially write the additional information for those, who may try the mode for themselves. So wish me luck!

I am a huge fan of the Amnesia franchise, and of Frictional's work. I was excited when the game came out, and got it immediately. Within a couple of hours, I was sick of the mechanics and bored. I took a break from it for a long time, and it took a year for me to convince myself to give it a second chance. Now, I can safely say I'm flat out disappointed. I hate this game. I hate that I hate it because I want to like it so badly, but it's just not a good game. This game is full of fantastic ideas that were HORRIBLY implemented. They just threw as many mechanics in as possible, and made the game feel messy, overly and unnecessarily complicated, and unrefined. While it's interesting that they went back to primarily using notes for storytelling, and I usually love that, they managed to make the game boring. The game feels like they don't understand the difference between fear and stress. The game is not scary at all. It's just stressful. The primary enemy isn't scary after the first couple times he shows up, and just becomes another tedious mechanic. The rats are just annoying, and I've died to them chasing me more than I ever died to the main enemy. Part of why I took a year long break was frustration with the excessive number of mechanics and the damn rats. I'm glad they added an option to make them not hurt you, as it dramatically improves the gameplay. The generator runs out of fuel rapidly, even with all the lights turned off, to the point that it's not even worth using because it'll run out before you ever get where you're going. I played most of the game without the generator because it runs out so fast, and it's so tedious to try to deal with. The inventory system is a stingier version of RE. This game also has mechanical issues. Items getting stuck, your character going flying up and down while hiding between boxes, and constant framerate drops out of nowhere, and in the middle of hallways that are being used as loading areas instead of a loading screen, which is another great idea that was horribly executed.

Lovely little horror game - reminiscent of Alien:Isolation. The scarcity of voiced journal notes (only two characters are voiced) means that the game relies much on written information for exposition this limits the accessibility of the story aspect.
[h1] 4.0 / 5 [/h1] Likely the best Amnesia since The Dark Descent.

A really good, more gameplay focused Amnesia-game. This one felt more similar to older frictional games, including the first Amnesia. Relatively short, but that suited me fine. The game has a few random elements that change for each playthrough, and after completing the game once you are able to customize future runs. This Amnesia-entry encourages creativity in the player, with multiple ways to solve problems and get past obstacles. You will find plenty of tools and consumables in the game that you'll need to escape the bunker, including some actual firearms this time around. The game is also non-linear, and you may explore the bunker in the order you wish. That said, some locations will require finding certain tools to access. Another important mechanic is the generator that provides the bunker with light. You will have to search for fuel during the game in order to keep the generator running. If fuels runs out, all the electric lights in the bunker go out - in turn allowing a certain creature to move freely throughout the bunker. At first this mechanic bothered me - but I grew to like it, as it encouraged a faster, more risk-taking approach to the game as you get the sense you want to make the most out of every second. Really solid game, with good balance of gameplay and narrative. Easy to recommend.

Masterpiece has a very similar vibe to Dark Decent; it's very apparent that you're playing a game from the team who made it. I bought this a while ago on a Steam Sale but just didn't get around to it until this week. This game does for me today what REmake on the GCN did for me back in 2002. This is without hyperbole one of the greatest horror games ever made. I have never been so scared of a game in my life, and yet the Immersive Sim element is done in such masterful fashion I couldn't stop playing. I wanted to stop but couldn't. Immersive Sim fans have been treated pretty well recently. Ctrl Alt Ego is an absolute masterpiece, as is Cruelty Squad. There are a number of indie ImSims coming up that look very promising as well. But Amnesia The Bunker took emerging gameplay elements and fused it perfectly with the survival horror genre. The product is a short but extremely sweet and absolutely relentless assault on your primitive prey instincts. Adding to the terror of my own personal experience with this game was the fact that since I hadn't been paying a whole lot of attention, I thought The Bunker was just a World War I game. Like a military survival sim. I was well aware of The Dark Descent but for whatever reason I was under the impression that this was going to be a gritty, realistic reenactment of trench warfare. The hilarity is that for the first five or ten minutes it certainly feels that way. I was almost underwhelmed by the opening. The graphics are by no means eye-popping. Sound and music were top notch though. However after my character sustained damage from a battle against Germany invading France, it soon becomes clear that something is terribly, terribly wrong. You wake up in a germaphobe's nightmare. Everything is dirty. Lights are flickering. You hear the occasional bomb muffled heavily by the armored underground fortress in which you now step. And one thing that dawned on me very quickly was this thought of "Huh. Everything's quiet, and I'm making a lot of noise. I mean my steps are really loud." After picking up a few notes and a disturbing photo as is standard fare in Frictional games, you find a single living person near the ruined, abandoned pantry. He tells you that the bunker has been abandoned-- its exit sealed by explosions. He gives you a couple general clues on where you can find the missing components to reopen the exit. He also asks you to kill him. But as you go to the pantry to pick up rounds to grant his grim ask, he disappears screaming. One of the things that amazes me about this game is the pacing. Some of you know I'm an Alien fan, partly because the first half of the movie is dedicated entirely to hard and soft world building. You're treated to something similar here because you're stumbling around in the darkness, and nothing is really happening. As you get acquainted with the layout you start noticing things like fuel canisters you can pick up, clothing to combine together to make bandages (these are things revealed to you in the trench opening), and rats scurrying about, into their little holes. You also start noticing other holes. Big holes. Holes that were not made by rats. And you start hearing things. In the walls. Something big. Not a rat. And yet still nothing happens. You arrive at administration office which will become your base of operations. There are two doors here, and I did notice-- big steel doors with locks. Hmm. The map is presented on the wall here in this office, and only here. You can't take it with you. Did you wander into the offices and get lost? Tough shit. Find your way back and look at the goddamn map in the office. And let me just say one of the most brilliant things about this game is how it deals with maps. I'm sick of minimaps. I believe a lot of times minimaps are used in lieu of good level design. If you throw a minimap into your game you don't have to have smart, cohesive level design. Because you have a minimap. I recently finished Dragon Age II and before it, Dragon Age Origins and as much as I love DAO, I found myself in both games focusing on the minimap instead of what was actually on the screen. In DA2 especially, some pretty bland level design uses this as a crutch and I just continually fell into this habit of watching the arrow go through lines in the corner of the screen. It was one of my criticisms of Skyward Sword which admittedly used "dowsing" instead which is creative, but still a crutch. One thing I will add is that as you progress into the other areas you will find appendices that will update your main map at base. But there is no minimap to be found in Amnesia: The Bunker. There is, however a handy dandy flashlight from the Civil War era, which winds up. You crank this thing a few times and it gives you about 15-20 seconds of light, and again I noticed--- "This thing makes a lot of noise." Not a chance THIS ever becomes an issue. Resident Evil-esque puzzles await you. A wheel to open a quarantine lock, a wrench to loosen bolts on vent covers that you can't take off otherwise, and the survival horror quintessentials, bolt cutters and lighter. The combining of cloth isn't just for bandages- you make torches, Molotov cocktails and probably other things I wasn't creative enough to figure out. There's a centralized locker room with essential items locked, and each one has a padlock whose combinations can only be found on dogtags you'll find throughout the bunker. Also every playthrough gives randomized combinations so on subsequent runs you won't be able to just beeline to the locker room and grab your shotgun, gas mask and other quest items. Nope, you'll have to go into the darkness and grab these tags to get the goods. Numerous light switches are found and serve as progression points for you. Sometimes you'll have to get a sequence of them, a chain if you will, in order for them all to function and give you visibility on precious resources and story notes. The immersive sim elements are perfectly folded into this masterpiece. You will often find that there are numerous ways to get where you need to go. This goes hand in hand with the fact that most items are randomized as well. The difference between wood and steel plays a crucial element here. There will be times when you won't be able to open a door without triggering a trap, or open it at all, unless you find a brick somewhere and bash the wooden frame out or use a grenade. It goes without saying that these methods also create a lot of noise. Keys exist, but you'll find that box stacking and the like are just as pertinent. Another really cool thing about this game is the weapons system. Ammo is scarce. I mean really scarce. I found twelve rounds for the revolver my first playthrough. And I only found five shotgun shells and never found the shotgun on the first run. These weapons are an absolute last resort. This is what you use when you have literally no other option. And to emphasize how important they are and yet how seldom they should be used, the loading mechanic is such that you hold down the R button to open the cylinder, and then you load each round individually one by one. Not that you'll have many fucking rounds anyway. I never had a full six in the chamber. If you have four, you're lucky. The shotgun is the same-- each shell is loaded individually. So even if you had a bunch of rounds to use, loading your gun is a dynamic in which you will not be able to reload in the heat of the moment. And did I mention that the generator located in the admin office, runs on gasoline, and will deplete? One of the most useful tools in the game is a timer that reads how long you have given how much fuel you've put in. When it runs out, it doesn't matter where you are--- all the lights everywhere go out, and you're plunged into darkness. And in the darkness, he comes out to hunt for you. I ran out of space. BUY THIS GAME. PLAY THIS GAME. SUPPORT THESE GUYS.

After helping usher in a decade long horror trend of playing hide 'n seek with invincible monsters, Frictional Games branched out into at letting players fight back. You're not going to be shooting up the place but you can deter the monster with things like firearms and explosives when you don't have somewhere to hide. The gameplay is tense, the primarily note-driven story is great for what it is, and the WW1 setting carries the game. Other than losing progress due to some sudden frustrating one hit kill deaths and my dumbass completely forgetting that the generator exists after taking a 1 month break between my first and second play sessions, I had a great time playing through this.

1. Animations locking your movement and not being able to stop them . 2. The game devs not being able to decide if it's going to concentrate on PVP or PVE . 3. Balancing the game in a way that favors neither casuals or tryhards. 3. Not adding any type of FOV slider ingame and using ridiculous excuses. For me an FOV slider would be a game changer . 4. Enemies are just bullet sponges .Why doesn't a bolter one shot the basic enemies? 5. The dialogues between characters are just too irritating . There's no substance in them. I don't want to break my immersion by space marines constantly yapping . 6. This game doesn't feel like you're playing as a space marine . Space marine 1 and Boltgun make you feel as if you're a space marine. 7. I don't get why did they nerf assault so much. They should take notes from Space marine 1 on how to get the game to be fun . Overall it's a forgettable game which has a campaign that is a poor copy of the first game. The graphics are good looking and it worked on release ,so I guess that's the bar for a successful game nowadays unfortunately.

Extremely weighty and meaty game. They absolutely nailed the feeling of a Space Marine: just a game about big meaty men stomping around covered in fridges, but it doesn't feel slow and cumbersome. Combat flow is fantastically punchy and rewarding once you get into it. Campaign is decently long and full of setpieces to shoot guys in, weapon variety is pretty solid, and all the DLC is purely cosmetic. Haven't touched PvP cus I don't care about PvP, but none of the cosmetics you can earn require you to play it, which is based. Downsides are that the story is boring, the characters are boring, and teams are limited to one of each class in coop, which would be fine if the game didn't matchmake you into groups that already have the class you've chosen. There's also not a huge amount of coop missions - this isn't WWZ yet - but the core gameplay is so satisfying at every level that it evens out the repetition. Also, there's a horde mode on the way. Certainly worth it, though maybe not at full Australian price. This game is so cool and feels so good to play that it almost makes me actually really like Space Marines, something GW has never managed to do. Go Saber

Definitely one of the most enjoyable games I've played in quite some time. Especially if you love Warhammer lore, or are just getting into it.

One of the best releases of the year. This game offers you a really great story mode alongside amazing gameplay, the swarm mechanic and the utter chaos of things happening around you make you really feel you are in a battlefield risking ur life for the one true GOD EMPEROR. The swarm mechanic of the tyranids is absolutely amazing, the heretics also good enemies but feel a little bit more shallow compared to the tyranids. Plenty of weapons which are all fun. One of the main things here are Amazing are the stunning graphics and visuals that are really well optimized, I can play the game with no screen tears nor fps drops which has been a common issue with most newer releases with various developers. The executions are absolutely stunning and simply put awesome with a huge variety of them depending on the weapon you have and the enemy you are facing. The campaign gives a fair challenge while not being too hard (played veteran mode) and there are no bugs that I've come across. So I would give it a 9.4/10 FOR THE GOD EMPEROR

Space Marine 2 feels like a complete game with full co-op support both campaign and PvE operations. I haven’t run into many bugs—other than the Tyranids. The campaign is short, took me about 8 hours to finish on my first run with two friends, but it was a blast. The operations add some good replay value, and the classes are well-balanced. Each one has its own strengths and weaknesses, and they work really well together. Not played the PvP mode so I can't really say much about that. I played Assault, while my friends went with Tactical and Heavy, and the combo worked perfectly. The Tactical abilities paired with the Assault’s jetpack and ground slam with the Thunder Hammer made quick work of bosses and elites. Meanwhile, the Heavy wiped out the smaller enemies and kept us covered with fire support. The teamwork feels smooth and satisfying. I’m really looking forward to the new Horde mode and the class prestige system. Lately, I haven’t been hyped for a lot of games because so many release unfinished or broken, but Space Marine 2 has been a nice change. It’s refreshing to play something that actually delivers. Plus, it doesn’t shove DLC and season passes in your face every two minutes. Sure, they show you the extras, but you don’t feel pressured to buy them. The base game has plenty of content on its own, and it looks like new operations and Horde mode will be part of a free update, which is awesome. To me, the DLC feels more like an extra way to support the game rather than something you need to enjoy it.

AAA style games should know how to manage optimization so this shit doesn't happen.

To quote my favourite meme of the early 2010's "DISAPPOINTED!" All of my play time has been in the co-op "operations" mode, getting hard carried by a friend on console who pre-ordered, and is long since done with everything in the game. So take my opinions of the gameplay with a grain of salt. With that caveat out of the way, lets get started! DLSS is a NECESSITY! Even when set to balanced I still drop below 80 FPS, meanwhile everything has that pre-teen puberty peach fuzz look to it. There's a film of fuzz like blur over everything that worsens with quick movements, which this game requires a lot of. My rig consists of a 4070 Ti/i7 13700k/32g DDR5 RAM etc. I play at 1440p and at default settings I was getting around 70 FPS while out of combat and not moving, I ended up Googling "best settings" options and even when following the many suggestions I found, I still struggle to maintain and keep above 100 FPS, as previously mentioned often dropping below 80. I play on KBM, and whoever decided what the default keybinds should be clearly has never played a game on KBM in their lives. Middle mouse to aim? C to block/parry? RMB and LMB being melee or shoot (blindfire) is also a strange decision that took me a solid couple hours to drill into my brain. Remember how I said I was playing co-op and crossplay? Yeah, about that. Mans is too old and technologically illiterate to figure out how to join a party, so I'm forced to join him - things are fine on his end, he's got a crisp 30 ping while mine skyrockets well over 100. Not only are things fuzzy and blurry, but they're also in stop motion. I feel like I'm behind the scenes of a claymation movie, striking a pose and snapping a still image. There is no fluidity to anything, everything feels like you're fighting delay, parries don't work, dodging (if you can call it that, even the infamous Dark Souls "fat roll" is more of a dodge than in this game) rarely works. I had decently high hopes. I have 0 knowledge of WH40k lore, but I've always been a fan of their design and the creatures etc in the WH universe(s). I've played practically every WH game (minus the RTS) from the 40k ARPG and Boltgun, to both Vermintide and Darktide - heck even Necromunda and Chaosbane! Gross. All this to say this is yet another game in the 2024 catalogue of unoptimized, uninspired and ultimately disappointing games of AAA games of today. I'm sure there is something to be enjoyed if you're able to look past these problems, or if you have a deep understanding and appreciation for WH40k. But for the average consumer like myself? I'm not sure I could recommend it. TLDR: Poorly unoptimized mess, more ping than a game of ping pong, and grossly anti gamer default keybinds on KBM. Likely better if you have a $40k PC and a deep understanding or appreciation for WH40k lore stuffs. Sadly for me, I am yet again Kevin Sorbo - DISAPPOINTED!

I didn't buy this game because I saw the game and liked it. I heard a story about this game and how it was produced. How much work was put into it. And aside from the beautiful art and animation and songs and how perfectly they captured the feel of those old cartoons, must say, this game is also genius in another way: I really dislike all these roguelike games where the room is polluted with bullshit where there's no escape from. Like harder levels of "Enter the gungeon" for example. In this game you have nothing to blame but yourself when you're hit. And i mean it! I am not a very good gamer and I managed on some levels to get through without getting hit. Because when you observe the patterns and know what#s coming you can position yourself. This is not at all possible in games where the enemies are generated at random. Procedually randomly generated was it called I think. This isn't here. It is all carefully planned out. And that I think is the best part. Nothing feels like unnecessary additions. Perfect game 10/10

[h1]Yоu knоw hоw а jоkе саn stаrt funnу, gеt аnnоуіng, thеn bесоmе funnу аgаіn thrоugh shееr аttrіtіоn?[/h1] [i]Тhаt’s Сuрhеаd’s аррrоасh tо еnjоуmеnt.[/i] [h1]- Sеttіng[/h1] 1930's-іnsріrеd аnіmаtіоn stуІе, аnd іf уоu'rе uр fоr dіffісuІt сhаІІеngеs (whісh і bеІіеvе mіght bе а ІіttІе bіt tоо hаrd fоr уоungеr рІауеrs tо соmрІеtе), wіth а vаrіеtу оf dіffеrеnt, соІоrfuІ ІеvеІs аnd wіth а gооd аnd fun stоrуІіnе, thіs gаmе іs fоr YОU. Тhеrе аrе Тwо сhаrасtеrs іn Сuрhеаd, sо Тwо РІауеrs саn рІау thіs gаmе, Сuрhеаd hіmsеІf аnd hіs brоthеr Мugmаn. Thе сhаІІеngеs уоu wіІІ hаvе tо соmрІеtе аІоng thе wау аrе аІwауs dіffеrеnt аnd fun. Аs уоu аdvаnсе fоrwаrd, ІеvеІs bеgіn tо gеt mоrе сhаІІеngіng, but thаt's thе fun раrt. Веwаrе! Сuрhеаd саn bе аddісtіng, Сuрhеаd саn kеер уоu uр рІауіng fоr mаnу mоrе hоurs аs уоu trу уоur hаrdеst tо соmрІеtе thе ІеvеІs. Вut bеtwееn ІеvеІs уоu gеt tо hаvе а brеаk аs уоu саn rоаm аrоund thе еxіstіng mарs аnd tаІk tо thе dіffеrеnt сhаrасtеrs, аnd buу usеfuІ іtеms (сhаrms, wеароns) frоm thе shорkеереr, "роrkrіnd", thаt wіІІ hеІр уоu іn hаrdеr ІеvеІs. Вut wе must nоt dіsrеgаrd thе bеаutіfuІ аrt stуІе! Тhе аrt stуІе іs unіquе аnd оІd-fаshіоnеd, muсh rеmіndіng mе оf 1930's аnіmаtіоns frоm рісturе соmраnіеs suсh аs FІеіsсhеr Studіоs. Аnd thе jаzzу sоundtrасk іn thе bасkgrоund іs just thе сhеrrу оn tор! Тhе fоundеrs mаdе аn еxсеІІеnt jоb, kееріng thе gаmе оrіgіnаІ аnd еntеrtаіnіng. АІthоugh І соuІd, аnd І dіd fіnіsh thе whоІе gаmе [spoiler] іn thіs hаrd 2024 НЕLL Yеаr [/spoiler] , І thоught bасk оf Сuрhеаd аnd rеmеmbеrеd hоw gооd thіs gаmе wаs іn sо mаnу wауs, аnd fеІt Ііkе І hаd tо rеvіеw thіs аnd rе-рІау іt wіth mу frіеnd аnd Ultramarin І’m tаІkіng аbоut YОU ВRОТНЕR @UltramarinUA! Тhіs gаmе dеfіnіtеІу dеsеrvеs 5 stаrs аnd dеfіnіtеІу dеsеrvеs уоur аttеntіоn іf уоu hаvеn't trіеd іt оut уеt! Wіthоut sроіІіng аnуthіng іn thе рІоt, thе sеttіng іs аІsо wеІІ-сhоsеn tо bе stаndаІоnе саrtооnіsh Unіvеrsе, whіІе stіІІ gіvіng gооd nоds tо thе аrtstуІе оf 1930s аnіmаtіоn stуІе – аІІ wаtеrсоІоr bасkgrоunds аnd surrеаІ, juddеrіng, hаnd-drаwn сhаrасtеrs – рау рееrІеss hоmаgе tо Mаx FІеіsсhеr аnd hіs іІk, аnd аrе реrfесtІу іmрІеmеntеd; [h1]- GаmерІау[/h1] Реrhарs Сuрhеаd’s smаrtеst, mоst dеvіІіsh аddіtіоn іs іn hоw аІІ thеsе tуреs оf ІеvеІs tаunt уоu іntо рІауіng mоrе. Nо еnеmу hаs а hеаІth bаr, nоr аn іndісаtіоn fоr whеn уоu’rе gеttіng сІоsе tо а knосkоut – іnstеаd, whеn уоu dіе уоu’rе shоwn а grарh оf hоw сІоsе уоu wеrе tо thе КО (*knосkоut) оr thе nеxt рhаsе оf thе bаttІе. Іt rеduсеs sсrееn сІuttеr whіІе аІsо еnсоurаgіng (оr реrhарs thаt shоuІd bе “bеrаtіng”) уоu іntо tаkіng аnоthеr сrасk аt іt. Bеst оf аІІ, thоugh, аrе thе рІаtfоrmіng bаttІеs. Thіs іs whеrе МDНR fІеxеs іts іmаgіnаtіоn mоst, сrаftіng wеіrd, оftеn hіІаrіоus bоuts thаt hаvе уоu іntеrасtіng wіth thе Ііmіtеd соntrоІ sсhеmе іn mоrе аnd mоrе іntеrеstіng wауs. Tаkіng оn thе wоrkеrs оn а ghоst trаіn hаs уоu nоt оnІу shооtіng еnеmіеs, but аІsо соntrоІІіng thе роsіtіоn оf уоur rаіІ trоІІеу рІаtfоrm whіІе stорріng mіnіоns frоm mоvіng уоu іntо dаngеrоus роsіtіоns. ВаttІіng аn асtrеss іn hеr thеаtеr tаkеs уоu thrоugh thе dіffеrеnt stаgеs оf а рІау, аnd thе соmbаt fееІs аІmоst Ііkе а fіghtіng gаmе аs shе dіvеkісks аnd usеs рrорs аs sресіаІ mоvеs. Оnе оf thе fіnаІ ІеvеІs сhаngеs thе struсturе еntіrеІу, turnіng а sеrіеs оf fіghts іntо а mіnіаturе bоаrd gаmе – іt’s аn аbsоІutе jоу, аnd uр thеrе wіth thе bеst bоss bаttІеs І’vе еvеr рІауеd. Реrhарs Сuрhеаd’s smаrtеst, mоst dеvіІіsh аddіtіоn іs іn hоw аІІ thеsе tуреs оf ІеvеІs tаunt уоu іntо рІауіng mоrе. Nо еnеmу hаs а hеаІth bаr, nоr аn іndісаtіоn fоr whеn уоu’rе gеttіng сІоsе tо а knосkоut – іnstеаd, whеn уоu dіе уоu’rе shоwn а grарh оf hоw сІоsе уоu wеrе tо thе КО (*knосkоut) оr thе nеxt рhаsе оf thе bаttІе. Іt rеduсеs sсrееn сІuttеr whіІе аІsо еnсоurаgіng (оr реrhарs thаt shоuІd bе “bеrаtіng”) уоu іntо tаkіng аnоthеr сrасk аt іt. [h1]- Stоrу[/h1] Іn thе mоmеnt іt’s frеnеtіс, but Сuрhеаd’s struсturе іs а Ііnеаr sеquеnсе оf thrее wоrІds fіІІеd wіth оnе-shоt ІеvеІs tо соmрІеtе, аnd а fіnаІе. Тhоsе ІеvеІs саn tаkе оnе оf thrее fоrms. Тhе Іеаst соmmоn – аnd Іеаst іntеrеstіng – іs run‘n’gun, Іеft-tо-rіght рІаtfоrmіng drаwn dіrесtІу frоm thе Ііkеs оf Соntrа. Bаrrіng оnе thаt hаs уоu rеguІаrІу fІірріng grаvіtу tо gеt thrоugh, thеsе аrе bоth thе еаsіеst аnd Іеаst іnvеntіvе stаgеs thаt Сuрhеаd hаs tо оffеr. Thеу’rе mеаnt tо рrоvіdе SОМЕ brеаthіng sрасе frоm еndІеss bоss bаttІеs, but thеу еnd uр fееІіng mоrе Ііkе а ІuІІ. [h1]- RерІауаbіІіtу аnd асhіеvеmеnts[/h1] Mу fаvоrіtе gаmе еvеr, sресіаІІу thе сhаІІеngе tо gеt S rаnks fоr еvеrу sіngІе bоss аnd run‘n’gun! 5/5 fоr а fuІІ рrісе іt’s wоrth еvеrу реnnу fоr аІІ thе wоrk thаt wеnt іntо mаkіng іt - hаnd drаwn 1930’s wау Ііkе thе mоvіng mаtсhstісk mаn mеthоd, еxhаustіng wоrk fоr а grеаt рrісе рІus grеаt jаzz musіс? Whаt саn І sау - buсkеt Ііst gаmе а mіІІіоn (1 000 000) % аnd соmраrеd tо еxреnsіvе trірІе а tіtІеs thаt аrе fаіr but fіrm сhаІІеngе just buу іt - аnd fuІІу еnjоу іt еvеn mоrе! I am so glad people loved this game. I wanted to love it. But I don't, and I am done. Even if I don't choose to keep playing it, I won't refund because I like to support Indie games. People say it is an immersive exploration game, but I just never found anything interesting while doing so. I feel like a game needs to hook you... just like a good book, or a good blog, or an article, or even a movie to some degree... you have to build interest. You have to hook the reader/player and make them want to learn more. This game gives you basically nothing. It promises story-telling glory, but you have to kind of just go on faith. I don't really like that, because I have no idea how much of my life I'm going to have to sink in order to find a nugget of this story, and even then I have no idea if I will actually like it. It doesn't help that I don't like the character design... I find them a bit awkward and strange, and not in a good way. But that is very personal, I'm sure people love them. The physics are fun but that lasted about... 5 to 10 mins. Then I found myself kind of just sitting back, one hand on the controller and daydreaming about other games while doing random circles in orbit around a rock. Honestly the whole thing became one big snooze fest. I even found some type of gravity well thing, in some kind of alien ruin? It had me walk down to the end and... die, I guess? I dunno. But even that was just not interesting. It didn't say anything, it was just there and without any context. There's no fun in that, it's like turning to a random page in a random book and reading a paragraph. By itself it has no value, especially when it neither uncovers any secrets nor provides any context whatsoever. I'm glad for people that loved this game, but I don't. And with the overwhelming majority of people putting up positive reviews, I wanted to get my thoughts out there.
play it.

7 hours in, and Outer Wilds has me completely entranced. The world-building is nothing short of incredible. Every planet feels like its own living, breathing enigma, packed with secrets waiting to be uncovered. The chaotic beauty of planets, space, and gravitational madness contrasts perfectly with the calm, reflective moments spent piecing together the mystery of this universe. Each discovery feels earned, each moment of curiosity rewarded. Whether it’s hurtling through space, narrowly dodging hazards, or sitting by a campfire listening to the ambient music, the game captures a perfect balance of wonder and danger. If you love exploration, mystery, and feeling like a small part of a vast cosmos, this is an absolute must-play.

It's a beautifully unique experience, a marvel of storytelling and game design. Easy and quick new top 1 game for me. Play it without spoilers, just go in blind. In my opinion, this is one of the best games ever made. If you’ve never played, please stop reading anything written and just experience it yourself. It’s well worth it. Also, please keep in mind that the DLC is NOT necessary and may well spoil your experience of the main game. Play it separately if you play it at all.

Since there is very little explicit direction in this game (just a small breadcrumb or two at the start and you're off to explore!), it can take a couple of hours for the game to really "click" and sink its hooks in, but I cannot understate just how worth the effort Outer Wilds is. This is one of the best exploration games I've ever played, absolutely packed to the brim with rewards for your curiosity, and a multitude of "aha!" moments just waiting to be discovered. This game is a masterclass in open world storytelling with no forced exposition. Each new bit of information you glean from logs, characters, or the environment is entirely up to you to make sense of, but each one is a valuable puzzle piece that compels you to craft and refine your existing theories on what is really going on out there. You'll laugh, you'll cry, you'll feel it all as the truth dawns on you in time. Saying anything more would rob you of one of the best interactive stories that I've ever experienced. I envy you for being able to play this game for the first time. Trust the other positive reviews, go into this as blind as you can, and get out there and explore!

Such an experience, extremely unique game. No combat, no complex mechanics. Just a universe to explore and a several stories to unravel. Took me a couple of try's before I was totally hooked but i'm very glad I gave it a chance. Apart from a couple of puzzles I was stuck on for quite a while [spoiler] Black hole forge [/spoiler] and [spoiler] The Ash Twin Project warp [/spoiler] the game somehow puts you on the right path without holding your hand. I wish you didn't have to hold the signal scope so often looking for clues it cuts out the really mysterious soundscape of an ost, such a minor gripe though. Truly a one of a kind game. [spoiler] I didn't expect the ending to be so emotional, does a perfect job of making you feel connected to these characters sharing a universe together. [/spoiler]

It really is one of the greatest of all time. The sense of discovery that comes with exploring Outer Wilds is in its own class; and the places it goes, no matter how bittersweet, have a kind of satisfaction few stories get to.
very cool game :)

December 15th - [B]Outer Wilds[/B] - 27h 24m - (Main+) 8/10 - Started December 5th - 10 Days Taken - Beat the main game and the DLC. Got 5/31 achievements. Here's my review: [b]Pros:[/b] Outer Wilds is a non-linear adventure game that encourages exploration. This could easily have resulted in a frustrating experience where players get stuck and don't know what to do next but it manages to avoid these traps by giving you leads on where to go next. A lot of the areas you explore will at some point, lead to some other area you need to learn more. This provides a logical next step for the player to follow. This worked so well that it was easy to [spoiler]do another loop[/spoiler] to explore the next area hinted at or apply the new knowledge I had learned. It made me play longer sessions than I originally planned because I kept saying "Just one more [spoiler]loop[/spoiler]". This system of leads, clues and knowledge is greatly benefited by the ship log, which helps organize and track all the information you have gathered so far. It removes a lot of the mental load off the player by not forcing them to remember all the information they've gathered throughout the entire game. It stores almost all the crucial information, such as the connections between various locations, even showing ones to locations you haven't visited yet, which can help prompt your next move. A great quality of life feature is that it tells you whether you gathered all the information within a specific area, which reduces player doubt and helps them be more focused in their exploration. In essence, the ship log removes the frustration of a non-linear mystery game without detracting from the player's feeling that they are solving the puzzles themselves and from receiving the eureka moments when things finally click together. Intertwining the story and the mysteries was a great choice. The more you explore and learn the more you piece together about the story. The story is quite a sad and tragic one. The [spoiler]Nomai were stranded in an unfamiliar star system and yet managed to persevere and almost reach the eye themselves. But they were wiped out by the ghost matter from the interloper at the last step. Then you step in, salvage it and reforge the galaxy anew. The game's time loop mechanic being part of the story all along was a shocking reveal[/spoiler] that meshes with the story perfectly. Echoes of the Eye complements the story further by adding a further layer of tragedy and sadness to it. The [spoiler]strangers got curious about the eye and sacrificed their entire planet to reach it. Once they did, they learned of its horrors, but by then it was too late. To retain their old way of life, they recreated their old planet virtually so they could still live out their lives on it. They even tried to stop the eye, so no other species could be lured to their doom like they were, but one rogue stranger released the eye's block for long enough for the Nomai to get attracted to the eye as well. However, in a twisted way, that act indirectly allows you the player to save the stranger's species by including them in the recreation of the universe.[/spoiler] Outer Wild's music is also important because while most of the time it is silent when it isn't, it plays well into the narrative and gameplay. It [spoiler]signifies when you're close to the end of a loop and that same music is played when you remove the warp core from the center of the Ashen twin to highlight the significance of what you're doing. I especially enjoyed the climactic music that played while in the Vessel after supplying it with the warp core. The best musical aspect of the game, however, has to be the main theme. You hear it every time you boot up the game on the main menu, but it's more than just that because every member of the Hearthian crew also plays one instrument of the song. This means you hear the song much more than you may think and results in the final scene hitting that much harder. You bring all the instruments together and finally hear the full complete version of the song during gameplay. [/spoiler] [B]Neutral:[/B] One nice QOL feature would've been the ability to [spoiler]restart at a loop[/spoiler] at any time without having to exit the game to the main menu and then resume the game because all it does is waste time. [b]Cons:[/b] There's only one part of the game that genuinely frustrated me and resulted in me having to use a guide to progress. That part was [spoiler]how to reach the first tablet in the Shrouded Woodlands.[/spoiler] I was conditioned to think that the solution to [spoiler]reach each tablet was limited to each area because that was the case with the second and third tablets, which I did before the first one.[/spoiler] I could've maybe figured this out by myself if I had a cool head and wasn't already frustrated to hell and back. What frustrated me you say? [spoiler]The Stranger's. To reach the previous two solutions you had to kite and lure the Strangers away from where they were standing so you could get past them.[/spoiler] This is a very action-heavy mechanic in a puzzle game and it goes against a principle that the base game strives for. This principle is that after you figure out the solution to a puzzle and have the eureka moment, actually executing it and getting your reward shouldn't be too difficult and take a long time. The longer it takes to reach the reward, the more the positive feeling of solving the puzzle diminishes. By adding the more action-based [spoiler]Strangers[/spoiler], knowing the solution wasn't enough and you had to [spoiler]kite and lure the Strangers multiple times in the dark.[/spoiler] Safe to say that this got quite frustrating after enough failed attempts. The only [spoiler]enemy[/spoiler] in the base game, [spoiler]the anglerfish had a clear weakness you could exploit[/spoiler] and after you figured it out, you didn't have to worry [spoiler]about them[/spoiler] anymore. The same can't be said for [spoiler]the Strangers.[/spoiler] They put a massive blemish on an otherwise wonderful DLC that explores a bunch of interesting and unique puzzle ideas.

The game was beautiful, and had a lot of cool elements, but ultimately I didn't find it fun enough to keep playing all the way through. Specifically the controls didn't work well and I didn't like the timed aspect - too stressful, and the repetitive nature of having to start completely over every time was frustrating.

You will never play another game like this. Period. The devs truly created something special here, and I cannot recommend it enough to anyone who is curious about this amazing story packed into the cute little package it's presented as. HOWEVER. At the risk of sounding like a gatekeeper... I think it takes a certain kind of person to truly appreciate what Outer Wilds is. If you enjoy piecing together a story yourself, if you like investigating and finding things out on your own, if you prefer not to look things up and form your own unique perspective on the stories you experience; then you will absolutely love this game and it will stick with you forever. To another kind of person, they get told this is the greatest game ever made, to go into the game as blind as possible and avoid any spoilers at all costs. They might play the game for an hour or two, and realize it's essentially a space exploration game with puzzle elements, and ultimately feel let down because their expectations were set so high. If you don't care as much about discovering a story on your own, if you just want to get to the core of the secret that this game so eloquently hides, then you might benefit more from simply watching a video about the game rather than playing it yourself. Which pains me to say, since I personally love this game and think it is best experienced by playing it through oneself. A good parallel to gauge your interest is how you approach the story of Elden Ring or other Soulsborne games. Do you like how those games present their stories in silence? Do you enjoy reading item descriptions, analyzing dialogue and the characters who give them, observing subtle details about your environment, and inferring meaning through all those things put together? Or do you prefer to just rush through bosses, accrue power, beat the game as fast as possible, and save the storytelling for various YouTubers to present it to you in a more compelling way? In conclusion, if you're still curious: Buy. This. Game. You won't regret it. The music, the atmosphere, the breadcrumb trails that lead you to revelation after revelation; it's all executed beautifully, and I think in a way it brought me closer to the universe, and emboldened my curiosity in general. Every time I look up at the stars, I hear that banjo melody in the back of my head. And that, I consider to be a priceless experience.

This is the best game I played in the last 5 years and one of the top 10 games I have played in my entire life. I don't remember when was the last time I felt such immersion and was so invested in the story. I literally felt like that was my world and I was the astronaut. This is not a regular game, you don't unlock any superpowers, you get all equipment right after prologue and nothing more throughout the whole play. The progress depends solely on your knowledge of the game and mechanics, so you need to focus on every information you get. The game is not hard, but some places can be very frustrating, especially when there is some platforming section which needs precise jumping. The good thing is, there are a lot of other, less demanding places and you can take a break anytime whithout any consequences because of the time loop mechanics. I really hate roguelike games where you have to start everything over and over again, but somehow in this game it didn't bother me at all. Each start felt like an opportunity to explore something different. The story was really good and finding each new piece of information gave me so much satisfaction. I wish I could forget everything and start over one more time. 10/10 Prepare for A LOT of 'deaths'

What to say about this game?! I'm only on 13hours on Steam but 400+ hours on PS5. Its the best game of the last decade, the best successor I've found to NWN2 which for me was the best D&D video game we'd had. Graphics are beautiful. Voice Acting is the best I've come across. Plot is very good, with lots of variations based on player choices. The scale of the game is incredible, I feel like every play through I find new things, and the multitude of endings is pretty crazy. The characters in the game are really well written with great personalities and thats another testament to just how good the voice acting is. Character creation is really good, huge amounts of variety from looks and play styles, The relationships between your character and the written ones is really dynamic and based on not just conversation decisions but also in game world decisions. Special mention to the Dark Urge plot line, which is a hybrid written in/player created character. The twists and turns that plot line takes is brilliant and I'm on my second Dark Urge play through now. So much I could write about this game. But you'd need to play it for dozens of hours yourself to understand.

I want it to be known that the 317 hours I have in the game (at time of review) was one playthrough. One. This game is long. And big. And ambitious. I played tabletop 5e for years and years before BG3 came out and I can tell you that it uses that system wonderfully and respectfully; as flawed and trash as that ruleset is. The combat plays out fine and the "homebrew" Larian put into the game is a welcome addition. The homebrew, and all the Larian-isms that come with the dev's title. Play Divinity: Original Sin 2, they have more freedom with that title than they did here, but this isn't a review about DOS2. I recommend this game if you have 300 hours to pour into an unknown title that is obviously a labor of love - despite it becoming an annoying, buggy mess as soon as you enter the third act. As long as you enjoy having to make tough choices and living with an unsatisfactory ending, where you have to imagine in your *headcanon* things actually went right. Its multiplayer is also a lot like DOS2. I played with my partners for a while and we disagreed on some moral decisions enough we decided to stop playing. It's really a 5e campaign you should play by yourself. I love this game. I hate this game. I beat this game one time in 300 hours. I've seen one ending. This game is too big.

Solid 9/10. I can see people ranking this a 10/10, but for me there's just a few grips: Enemy animations feel really slow, and having the ability to skip the party member animations but not the enemies feels like a waste. Especially when enemies can get upwards of 8 turns, then you're kinda just sitting there twiddling your thumbs hoping it ends soon. Going from the 4th party member to the 5th feels like it takes a lot longer than going from the 5th to the 6th. Now maybe that's just me because it took a full extra real life day to get them, but idk. Also wish you could trade money for MAG, seeing as I had a surplus amount of money leftover at the end of the game but barely enough MAG to get the final form for each companion. Now the good stuff: I really loved how [spoiler] there is a character for each race, just wished that there was a permanent Rhoag member along with us. Rest in peace goat Grius [/spoiler] In my opinion the Bond system is a lot better than the previous iterations. Letting us fully see what rank we are, instantly ranking up to the next one without needing spend extra time with them, and getting some extra MAG to help beef up our companions. Unfortunate that there's no romance system, but that's alright. Not every game needs a romance aspect to the relationship system, I personally prefer not having one for this game. Every since Archetype felt really fun to play, from getting the Gunner at first to completely decimate foes, to getting the GOAT Faker letting any ally add turns. And my goodness the reset battle feature *chef's kiss* letting the player not reset the whole game just to redo a single battle, so nice. Using this along with Faker's Roguery at the start of battle so that I can just start with 2-4 extra turns. It feels like they took notes on all the good aspects of previous main parties, and incorporated them into these one's. Loved every single party member. And finally the fact that we get the guide at the start of the game instead of halfway through the game

Short version: good but not great writing, but the gameplay is great -- especially if you enjoy job systems. As far as the writing is concerned, the people making this game had a point they wanted to make, and everything they wrote focused on it. It was well done, and as grumpy / picky as I am about writing, I still felt it was overall good. They had a goal in mind, and they achieved it. The writing isn't as good as Baldur's Gate 3 -- which isn't saying much since few games hit that level -- but the background NPCs get updated dialogue throughout the game. It reminded me of a Trails game, although it's not as tight / in depth. Anyway, if I play a RPG like this and only one of the party members irritates me, that's a win. The gameplay is dynamite. You level your characters as well as their jobs, so there's a lot of number go up to give you happy brain itches. The major fights in the game make you think, but they also aren't unforgiving slogs where you have to min-max every little thing. I play games to be just challenged enough to enjoy winning, and this game landed right in that groove. There are optional bosses at the end of the game that require more finesse (especially the final one), but for the base stuff it's not difficult to cruise through. I also enjoy the rhythm of the game. You have a deadline, load up on side quests, then cruise around the map knocking stuff off / building character relationships / training up your characters. The fact you get a home base is a plus, I always love having a base in a game. Sadly, there's no upgrading for this one, but I still like that sense of home versus being stuck in an endless parade of campsites for an entire RPG. If you do a lot of the side content, then you can also skip a decent number of turn-based battles in the main quest dungeon which really improves the flow. Overall, if you enjoy JRPGs, you'll enjoy this. No caveats.

(Very mild spoilers) I was having an absolutely fantastic time with this game until the final month. It's here where the pacing of the game nosedives and you are forced to grind for hours to keep up with newer enemies. The amount of MAG the game gives you becomes a pittance compared to how much it costs to unlock classes and moves, which I found to be detrimental to my ability to edit my characters and make builds for specific encounters. And the game is all the worse for this because the entire time you're grinding or bashing your head against annoying bosses and trying to make new builds to counter them, you're not experiencing the excellent story, which I just wanted so badly to see the end of. Obviously, many people seem to have no issue with this section given all the GOTY nominations and awards, but for those of us that have been put off by other RPG's because of the need to grind, the final month of Metaphor feels like a trap set to either force you to spend time doing something you hate or to get you to give up and set the game to easy mode or story mode.

Metaphor is a game I really enjoyed and definitely deserved its run for GOTY as a nominee, and as I am quickly approaching the end of my NG+ playthrough for the 100% achievements I can strongly recommend buying this as this whole game from start to finish was fantastic and definitely worth picking up if you can afford to. That being said I do have a minor issue that I want to raise, I love my Steam Deck and especially playing games like Persona on it as it allows me to jump between my desk and my couch or wherever, and whilst I think Metaphor is great on PC I am a little disappointed with its performance on Steam Deck. After Persona 3 Reload which ran fantastically and felt right at home it was a real shame to see the lack of care put into Metaphor's compatibility with the device. And yes it is just lack of care as the game arguably looks worse than some other Atlus games (like the aforementioned Persona 3 Reload) and yet runs noticeably worse than it. It absolutely does run and is enjoyable however towns absolutely chug (sometimes sub 20-30fps) and there are a multitude of tiny hard to read text boxes and alongside the forced letter-boxing for 16:9 is just not necessary, who knows maybe a future update will rectify all of this as it is simply a case of optimising for the device but as for now if you have the option to play on a PC rather than Steam Deck, I would recommend you play it there. Overall Metaphor is a solid game from a quality game developer. Feels and plays very similarly to both Persona and Shin Megami Tensei, a really good balance of mechanics and freedom. If you like the Persona games to any degree, you will also like this game.
Maybe the real Metaphor: ReFantazio was the friends we made along the way

There's a certain prescience about Metaphor: Refantazio. After November's utter fustercluck of a political landscape, I honestly think Metaphor's themes and ideas took on a new form that united a lot of people. The tough outlook of the world has and will be used as an excuse to delve ourselves into Fantasy and seclude ourselves from that horror. Metaphor challenges that notion, suggesting and promoting the struggles of fantasy that often go ignored. The racism, classism, beliefs, abuse of institutions such as monarchy, religion and military. Now these themes aren't things that are ignored in fiction, many works of fiction tackle them as key centrepoints of their narrative, but seldom as a theme or point of discussion, rather as decoration for the plot. Metaphor addresses these struggles and asks an honest question. "Can fantasy be used as a means to craft an ideal future?" The book in Metaphor, a novel that depicts a utopia where everyone forges their own destiny and creates a future everyone can believe in, is addressing the utopias we create in our world. Do we write and read worlds of idealism without these struggles as a means to escape our world or as an outlet to portray our ideal futures? We criticise media that portrays worlds as realistic or overlooking cruelties that society create, something that the cast of Metaphor do regularly as a means to question aspects and idealism in the real world, but is that not promoting discussion to create a more ideal future? I believe thinking about how the world can improve and how we make better futures is a pivotal aspect in art that everyone strives to interpret, and those thoughts can shape the views of youth and idealists whom seek to change the world. What society needs to do is put their words forward and help make the world better, bit by bit, in the hopes we can create that better future. One of Hope instead of one of desperation. Anyway, Metaphor is a very great game. I love the world in this game so much, being so fleshed out and diverse with strong characters and viewpoints that color it's landscape far deeper than many others I've seen in games. It's rare that everything has felt so cohesive in a story like this, and I think this is one of Hashino's best aspects of a writer. In fact, in my eyes, this is the best written Atlus title by a wide margin. I prefer the stories of Persona 3 and 5, but Metaphor's overall writing and perspectives are so grand in scale and rich in thought that I can't help but enjoy every second spent in this world, as cruel as it is. I don't disagree about the points about it's subtly, it's fairly blunt in it's approach. That said, I feel like this game, more than most, earns it's approach owing to the world as it is now. This message needs to be heard, loud and proud, and it's not as though the conversation is blunt at all, it's got a lot of strong perspectives and nuance to how these themes are portrayed and discussed in-narrative. The best compliments are reserved for the main cast though. While Strohl, Hulkenberg, Bastilio and Eupha are all great, my biggest compliments go to Heismay and especially Louis. If I've taken anything from this year, these two characters are proof that Atlus can write compelling as hell characters that reflect both the great and awful in the world, especially Louis who is undoubtedly my favorite villain of the year. The gameplay is pretty standard Atlus-flair, but considering it's building off years and years of Shin Megami Tensei's designs and ideas, it feels refined to the point of perfection. The game honestly feels harder than the majority of Atlus' previous titles, it honestly felt like I was playing Persona 3's cruel gameplay systems again. It's good stuff, and the archetypes and enemy design keeps the model distinct. I do wish the dungeons had a bit more variety in all, I only really felt as though the Cathedral and Louis' Runner had strong dungeons overall and the side dungeons were pretty bland, but that's honestly not a huge complaint. I feel as though it's hard to explain how special Metaphor is as a title. While it lacks some of the sheer political teeth of games like Disco Elysium, I feel as though the sheer cruelty and optimism of Metaphor Refantazio are better reflected and representative to the world as a collective. It's honestly such an amazing game to me. It's not quite up there as Persona 3 or 5, but, honestly, I'm more inclined to be happy with Metaphor owing to it's status as a new IP. With the bar set up with Metaphor, I am so goddamn excited for what comes next with this IP. 9/10. Feels like a goddamn antidote to the past few months of negativity. Can't wait for what comes next from Hashino and his team.

The first impressions always matter. And although im giving it initialy a negative review - doesnt mean its a bad game because i think it has alot going for it. But its held back by inconsistency in all areas from visuals to sound to technical issues - it feels like 3 teams made one game and it constantly switches between these 3 very different experiences! I will keep playing through the prolog and trust in others saying its the best when the real gameloop starts. Negative points summary: - technically messy with frequent stutters between transistions - many many loading screens (yes also on nvme!) - poor antialiasing requiring supersampling together with reshade to make it decent - graphics and style vary alot from good to poor - cutscenes are inconsistent switching from ingame to high fps fluid to low fps cinematic - audio is inconsistent with overlaps, abrupt ends, wierd directional mixing and varies in quality - gameplay constatly switches from fixed cam to free cam making it feel like seperate games from different times - (english) voice acting is only partialy included and even the main quest demands to read alot - it constantly switches back and forth and this is a big big issue here - full voice acting would benefit the game ALOT! Overall a very mixed bag and definately NOT worth a AAA pricetag or the title "masterpiece" ...

I absolutely loved this game! Overall I thought it was well-paced, and I only had to do a bit of grinding near the end to complete the optional towers/bosses. The story was fantastic and had some great twists, and as far as the gameplay I felt it streamlined a few of the things that kept me from finishing the Persona games in the past, and expanded on others in interesting ways. I especially loved the ability to change every party member's archetype and swap in abilities from other learned archetypes, opening up some very powerful combinations for managing the tougher bosses near the end. Highly recommend, 9/10!

Project Re:Fantasy, now known as Metaphor Re:Fantazio, has been in the works for more than 7 years, and it shows. It always sounded interesting, especially with the many recommendations by Yoko Taro - the director of Nier. From the team that gifted us Persona 5, a game that I deeply loved although my first real entry point to the genre, I had expectations of nothing but excellence, and I'm really glad I was right. Extremely minor spoilers about the intro ahead. [h1]Not just Fantasy[/h1] The story of Metaphor Re:Fantazio is set in the fantasy world of Euchronia, a land that is deeply divided in racially-motivated political and religious conflict between the core 8 races that inhabit it. Its political and social topics are incredibly contemporary, to almost an uncanny level. This world spoke to me in ways Persona never has. Maybe it's because I'm more interested in fantasy than contemporary stories, or maybe because of the current climate in the world. As if releasing it before November was a way to strive and encourage change... We play the role of the Hero, who's part of a resistance, on a mission to infiltrate the army. The objective is to learn more from a contact they have in it, in regard to a curse that has been plaguing the Prince of the land for more than 10 years, leaving him in a comatose state. With us, the magical fairy Gallica serves as a guide in our adventure. The Hero always carries, and is very attached, to a novel the Prince used to read with him, where a utopia is described: a land where conflict doesn't exist, there is no racial discrimination and everyone lives in harmony. This land that eerily reminisces of our world is naught but fantasy for them, as this world is fantasy to us. The story is narrated to us at points by a narrator, almost as if you'd be listening to an audiobook, and it's a beautiful way to really make you [i]live[/i] the fantasy. There's no shortage of good writing and twists, personally keeping me hooked the whole time. The [b]art direction[/b] of the game is one of the best I've ever seen, no wonder it won a Game of the Year for it. Each new area is stunning, from the great city of Gran Trad to the shores of Brileheaven, the game is polygonally and artistically superior to all other games in the Persona series I've played. Worth mentioning is the [b]music[/b] in the game, which while featuring fewer tracks than usual, is an extreme banger and is the only thing making me happy about finishing the game: I get to listen to it on [b]repeat[/b]. [h1]The Archetype of Persona[/h1] Coming from the same developers, I had somewhat of an idea of what the game would look like, and, indeed: Metaphor Re:Fantazio does follow a lot of concepts that are part of the Persona series. Starting from the [b]quotidian nature of its story[/b], having the player follow the Hero not through a told X amount of months, but actually play and live them, day by day with rare time-skips. Each activity takes half of the day to complete, with dungeons taking the whole day when coming back. Nothing can be skipped. [b]Confidants[/b] are back, with many people along our journey becoming close friends of ours and asking us for help in their disadventures. Each new confidant unlocks new powers, called Archetypes, and leveling the confidant up gives said archetype family more options. These are especially improved in Metaphor Re:Fantazio, with none being a second thought or a rejection of writing. All companions were as good as some of the best in previous Persona games, and although there is not an option to romance any of them, part of me is happier. I'm sure the devs would have again limited who I could romance, so I'd rather leave it to interpretation, personally. [b]Archetypes[/b], similar to Personas or Stands from JoJo Bizzarre's Adventure, are back as the main magical power we use to cast many spells and abilities, but compared to the other games, the limitation of having only the Hero being able to use all of them, is no more. All characters can use all Archetypes, with no limits but their true final form. I preferred this approach over Personas. Leveling an Archetype unlocks some of its abilities to be purchased for an in-game currency to be equipped by other archetypes; i.e., I had my main Warrior stacked with healing abilities. Even at max confidant level, you can't completely erase the nature of an Archetype with inherited skills, because you'll always be limited to max 4. On the other hand, in Persona you do this by using Skill Cards you obtain as loot from enemies, without any limits to what you can overwrite. With most, if not all, abilities being a Skill Card, I rarely found myself choosing a Persona over another instead of just "installing" all the abilities I wanted on the Persona that looked the coolest. Additionally, although some fan-favorite designs are back, all enemies and Archetypes are brand-new designs, whereas Persona has the tendency to normally reuse all enemies and Personas from previous games while adding new ones. The [b]UI[/b] is again a masterwork, with incredible designs and animation for each menu, blending both 2D and 3D together. Perfectly fitting of the art style, and with an amazing sound design. A feature to kill lower-level enemies in "[b]action mode[/b]" of Persona 5 you'd get from a confidant at level 7 is expanded, making it now a base feature and expanding it with a dodge, movesets for each weapon family, etc. Therefore, over-leveling is a great choice if you prefer the action-oriented approach when exploring dungeons while keeping the turn-base for bosses. Worth mentioning: in turn-based having the hero die in the fight won’t force a reset anymore! [url=https://youtu.be/CM7o8NtRgRQ][h1]OH LORD! Again, a-f-gain. Nothing new, nothin' changed. Same old shi.[/h1][/url] Reader, I'm going to level with you. When I saw the first trailer of the Persona 3 Remake, I rejoiced they were using Unreal Engine, whereas normally I'm disappointed when devs do that - the industry needs diversity, over a messy unoptimized engine used by everyone 'cause easy. If it wasn't for the Fox Engine, MGS:V would have never run on PS3. When I saw the first trailer of Metaphor Re:Fantazio and noticed the familiar shimmering of the AA my reaction was the same as in the above title. Persona 5 has many positive sides: its engine is not one of them. At the demo's launch, the performances were a mess, and overall the engine just doesn't stand the test of time in both feature and fidelity. The worst offender is when traveling outside the city on a vehicle, with the areas around it being very scarce and low in density and detail. Metaphor Re:Fantazio, again has an atrocious AA, helped by the option to render at higher resolution internally. Thankfully they patched in FXAA a few days after lunch; better than SMAA. Textures are passable, but up close in some cutscenes, it really is a bit of an eyesore for a next-gen game only; some could have a higher quality. I'm not sure if now all features available from the mod Metaphor Fix are in the game, but I strongly suggest using it for both skipping the intro, disabling the continuous camera noise which adds to the bad AA, and especially the depth-of-field and lines when sprinting. [h1]𝔗𝔥𝔢 𝔈𝔫𝔡[/h1] Metaphor Re:Fantazio learns from the mistakes of Persona. It delivered a stunning package that spoke to my very core and kept me hooked the whole way through. Not a better package, but one that stands with the best we've got so far, adding itself to that upper echelon of JRPGs you suggest to the people you [i]really[/i] like, excited just at the idea you'll get to talk about it with one more person. From the demo in September, to the release in October, to my month-long pause and return in December: this game lived rent-free in my mind and it will continue doing so in my playlist. This story ended, but the fantasy? That lives on. [b]8.5/10[/b]

What an incredible game, I haven't had so much fun playing a RPG in a looooooooong time. Persona 3R came out, that game is great but I think Metaphor really pushed the dev team to their limits and succeeded. Starting off with the bad: - The ending sort of becomes a little bit convoluted and "anime-ish/generic" but what do you expect from a JRPG? Especially from an ATLUS game, every ATLUS game ending will always go all out, and there's nothing wrong with that. Just wish some things were cleared up a little bit better, but by no means is it impossible to follow. I do think that the topic of "anxiety" becomes INSANELY overdone towards the end of the game, to the point where it IS THE GAME. Yes, people have anxieties but can we do it less generic? I'm sure FFXIV's Endwalker wasn't the first to do it but this game's finale really reminded me of it bar for bar. Like I said, it's a JRPG so I shouldn't be too surprised. - (NITPICK) Endgame grind is real and was kinda annoying to go through, especially facing the last 4 optional dragon bosses. They're entirely optional of course, but simply getting to the level where I could actually do stuff against them was a bit annoying. That is indeed a skill issue on my end though. Grinding in this game was definitely the lowest part but that's just because I wanted to complete everything on this play-through. This was entirely optional, and can be skipped. - I do wish the some of the dungeons were better laid out, the designs are really tedious to get around. I think this is a common complaint though so I'm not the only person who thinks of this. - Biggest gripe of this entire game is not being able to respec the main character, why? Several games give you the option to respec, why couldn't this one do it? Building a mage character, and having some of the best archetypes strictly doing phys damage is kinda annoying. However, every time you level up you do gain a random increase to a stat so that's good, it still remains balanced to an extent. I just feel like if the player (like me) regrets increasing a stat and not being able to change it back is just dumb. - Royal Archetype unlock requirements, ESPECIALLY FOR HEISMAY. WHY? - This might bug a lot of people out but for the social links (followers), Ranks 2-7 are not voiced which is a bit disappointing because all the VAs (in English) are fantastic and I would've loved to hear more of them. - SUPER NITPICKY but I absolutely hate that the game doesn't tell how to activate follower ranks, by that I mean some of the bonding scenes can ONLY happen on the gauntlet runner. - Another nitpick is that once in combat, you CANNOT open the main menu to reload, change your options, anything. It is super frustrating. - I do think the game can be really repetitive once you got the perfect party composition, but man, I just like hitting big numbers. The Good: - Art style; The first thing you see once you start the game. It's incredible what the artists did with this game and its designs. There's something so simple and designed on every single character, they're not too complicated nor boring, they're just perfect. Same goes for the monster (humans) designs, I know they're based off the paintings from Bosch, but seeing a human in this game is actually kinda jarring in a good way. They're so unique and I feel like that is what's needed in games nowadays, to just be WEIRD. The menu design, the painterly aesthetic, everything about this game is incredible to look at and is never an eye sore. What's really an eye sore is some of the animated cutscenes, my god, some are just... really bad. Still shouldn't distract from how well crafted everything looks in gameplay. - World building in a new IP will always be insanely difficult to pull off, especially when it's a fantasy game. Here they actually managed to not only create a well-put together world, but to have it actually be different from other games is incredible. A lot of people will call this game "DEI crap" but I really like how there's conflict and prejudice between each and every race. Going across the world you see how terrible everyone is to each other and it drives home the idea that you really need to fix what's going on and become king. There's also segments in the game where the party will stop in scenic locations and it's so cool to see landmarks throughout the world that aren't really explained. They're just, fantastical. - The Characters; I don't think I disliked any of the main cast at all, in-fact they're all really great characters. Surprisingly the ENG dub is really, really good? I've always found myself playing subbed JRPG games, but since this was a fantasy medieval-ish game I went with English. I'm actually kinda shocked that I can't listen to the JPN dub at all lol. Each character has their own conflict that you have to solve, and each bond provides an outlook on society; racism, hate, betrayal, loss of family, loss of trust, religion fanaticism, economic disparity, anxiety etc. In my opinion I believed there was never a dull moment, or a moment where the game just rubbed it in my face that "le racism bad". I do like the message of the game that fantasy can indeed be reality, but it needs time. My only pet peeve is that since this is an ATLUS game, only the main character can spend time with them one-on-one. Of course there are times where the party does come together and bond, but I really, really wish there was more of that because I do think they actually bond well with one another unlike certain games. Overall, great party, but I do wish Eupha's dialogue wasn't about magla 90% of the time. I do also wish that the MC had more of a personality trait than being the all-good optimistic character. Still, having a VA for the MC works wonders and he's not half bad either. - Louis, genuinely steals the show every time he's on screen. - The music is amazing and there's nothing else I need to say about it. - Gameplay is insanely fun once you get used to it. A lot of people will get turned off as soon as they see the archetype menu, but I personally think it's great. It has this mix of old FF games combined with obviously SMT/Persona and made a beautiful Metaphor baby. There's so many combinations to mix and match, my brain though is very small when it comes to tactical games so I didn't put it to its potential. However, the difficulty of the game is just perfect. I played this game on HARD and it's definitely the best difficulty for a new player, the game actually makes you think. I think early game is almost impossible, but once it hits, it hits. I've seen a few people complain about the MP issue and I saw almost none of that. If you run out of MP just take the day off the dungeon and return back? Anyways, this game was so fun to play it makes me actually want to play more turn-based RPGs. Also the inclusion of the front/back row is so awesome, would love to see more that in future games. In conclusion, I did enjoyed this game, and it was well worth the full-price I paid for. Will everyone like it? Obviously not, there are a lot more issues than what I stated, but having put 90 hours into completing almost everything was very fun. This is definitely one of Sega's best games to ever be released, and I'm so glad to have played it. Fantasy lives on.

Atlus went back to making story rich games with well written characters that are easy to like and hate. A pleasant return to form for Atlus, who I had feared had lost their way with the mistake that IMO Persona 5 was story and character wise. Thankfully they also have kept the positive aspects of Persona 5, namely the technical parts of that game that were indeed very good. A very solid game and a very interesting choice of story by Atlus, veering off from their usual Persona story telling but not missing the mark. Very good game overall.

This game is quite literally unplayable without an internet connection and if your internet happens to drop briefly while the game is launching it will lock you out from being able to play the game for 24hrs (at least according to their support article, I didn't wait to find out, I got a refund instead). This is a single-player RPG with optional online components. Having an always-online requirement for DRM is stupid, malicious, and disgustingly anti-consumer. Having third-party DRM on a Steam game when Steam itself is already a DRM platform is the same. No one should ever purchase a game with third-party DRM, especially Denuvo, under any circumstances, for any reason, ever. I wish I had noticed the warning about Denuvo on the store page, I wouldn't have bought the game if I had. But that's my own fault, it's spelled out on the page, I just didn't look for it. I'll consider re-purchasing the game when Sega/Atlus decides to remove Denuvo. Until then, I cannot recommend this game, and in fact recommend against purchasing it.
