My game of the year.

Takes all the things that made the previous Persona games great, and improves them further. The class system has a lot of depth, the game's turn system adds a lot of nuance and strategy that wasn't really seen in other Persona games, and above all else, its way of having you wipe out low-level scrubs without getting into turn-based combat at all keeps the game from becoming a slog. Only complaint is the dungeons are not nearly as interesting as they were in Persona 5. This is also my favorite story that Studio Zero has written. Doesn't suffer the same dips in pacing that other Persona games had, and has an amazing main villain that stays important throughout the whole tale. And of course, Atlus' solid character writing still remains in its 'followers' (think Social links). None of the followers were real duds to me, and some like Alonzo were absolutely phenomenal. If you have the time for another 80-100 hour JRPG, you can't go wrong with this one.

The experience is like buying a €70 vinyl full of exquisite music and getting a game on top. This is not your typical game with a braindead amount of action but rather a story you can take part in and influence its course. The main story structure covers a wide variety of political, sociological, and anthropological questions. If you've ever played any of the Persona games, you will enjoy this. The different setting is satisfying, and the art direction, combined with the sound design, is wonderful. The combat music feels jumpy, ecstatic, and energetic, which helps you get into the fight even more. It is a perplexing and twisting story bearing deep messages. It constantly uses every tool at its disposal to pull you in and live out its story with the characters. It's a bit shorter than Persona 5 but doesn’t lack anything that Persona provides. I would say it even improves upon previous ATLUS segments. I really appreciated the Magla reward from dialogue options rather than relationship points. Also, killing lower-level enemies in overworld combat is a lot easier, which is a change I’ve longed to see. As with any JRPG, the gameplay gets repetitive after a while. However, for me, it only felt that way in the last 5 hours, meaning the game constantly throws new things at you to keep it fresh. But there are also downsides. Storywise, I really hated the first two weeks after the Opera incident. For some reason, it didn’t keep me as invested as other parts of the game. Also, the later party members [spoiler]Junah, Eupha, and Basilio[/spoiler]—felt very rushed. [spoiler]Basilio[/spoiler] especially. He comes in too late in the story, and getting to know him and integrating him into the party is awkward at best. His voiced opinions feel forced most of the time. [spoiler]Also, he recovers instantaneously from the death of his brother, which felt really out of place[/spoiler]. I absolutely agree with the directive decision to not provide a love interest option, as the story and setting are not fitting for such a mechanic. What I lacked in a world full of despair, anger, and injustice was violence. I expected the story to be more brutal. That would have been more polarizing and could have further portrayed the protagonist as the shining beacon of hope. We also lack any character that is downright evil. I missed having anyone as disturbed as Kamoshida from Persona 5. You would expect that the harsh world of Metaphor: Re Fantazio would produce more people like him. In the end, I would definitely recommend the game, even with its few painful parts. It was a brilliant ride. Go try it for yourself. The fantasy lives on.

We come to this place for magic. We come to Metaphor: ReFantazio to strike, to pierce, to slash. Because we need that, all of us. That indescribable feeling we get when thy long-stagnant stance hath finally been broken. And we go somewhere we’ve never been before. Not just awakened but somehow reborn, together. 60 FPS on an LCD Steam Deck. Fervent Esperanto chanting that I can feel. Somehow ripping your own heart out feels good in a place like this. Our heroes feel like the best part of us, and stories feel perfect and powerful. Because here, they are.

Atlus is growing up, and holy shit it was worth the wait. The genre-defining JRPG experience without tedium, and a story line that actually makes sense — while still retaining the iconic flavor of the outright weird.

Heavy in the Persona like social aspects where you develop social bonds with the other characters to gain better skills or unique skills traits. Has an okay story, somewhat predictable though. There are some fun answers you can choose from but won't ultimately change anything when it's just the goofy part of the story. Over all it's an 7.5/10 for me. Thankfully you can restart the fight right in the beginning. Unless ALL the players are charmed, paralysed or anything else in between. Then you have to wait your turn for them to get their shit together or die.

8.5/10 First ever Atlus and turn-based game that isn't old school Pokemon. Finished the campaign in ~72 hours on normal difficulty. Game is very good and has some great characters, but at the same time has a lot of characters that i really didn't care about and doing their bond rankings was a drag so i just skipped it. I do not recommend this game if you don't like playing visual novels and there's A LOT of reading and it's hard to be engaged that long, especially given the length of the game. Criticism i have on the game is that the enemy and dungeon variety is poor, even all the dragons look sort of similar and has the same posture. At the end, they re-used the the humans that we've beaten already but slightly recoloured. They could have extended their imagination and made more different enemies and dungeons. At the end game, they literally made me go to the same dungeons that i was already at. Some dungeons are just way too long, especially the dragon temple which took me like 4 hours and 3 in-game days since i keep running out of MP and there isn't a good way to sustain MP without spending time farming, which i wished i did. I also didn't have enough time to get all the royal virtues and thus the royal archetypes, i thought i had enough time so i was focused on raising my combat stats whenever i had time in the Gauntlet, don't do this. I do wish this game was shorter and sweater, less dialogue diarrhea in between. The game also lacks some QoL features such as when i can save the game, pausing the cutscenes (there is a lot, sometimes i'm forced to sit through 20 minutes of cutscenes without the ability to pause or save, terrible QoL), and i can't access the main menu during combat. Some times i enter battle with a bad party and have to restrategize, but there's no way to load up an old save without Alt+F4 the game to go back to the title screen, super super annoying and discourages us from re-strategizing, especially annoying because strategizing is important to exploit enemy weaknesses. Last criticism i have on the game is how NG+ works, with how you have to re-unlock all the archetypes. The reason why i would want to play NG+ is because i want to experience my OP archetypes some more, but now i can't do that until end game when i earned those archetypes. Super lame and so i am unlikely to replay this game anytime soon, if ever. Also, fuck those skeleton mob, hard to avoid their ambush and i laugh everytime they get me (almost every time) because of how BS it is, they attack faster than you and have a very small window to attack or they lunge off screen so i don't even see them coming, and they're super strong when they ambush you. Good things about the game is the story, the animations, and characters. I especially loved the 30 fps animations that you get everyone once in awhile, i wish we got a lot more of that because obviously the graphics are very bad so those animations brought lots of clarity on the environment. Art style is very very good and i like the dark theme, but the poor graphics diminished it, hence why i liked the high resolution 30 fps animations/cut scenes. I also like how they tied this game to Etrian Odyssey, never played it and don't know what that game is until i watched a video on it and found it to be super cool. Overall, great game and a good experience into Atlus, i am now excited for their upcoming work. Will unlikely play their older games because they lack a lot of QoL that Metaphor has fixed such as how dialogue options work to increase bonds. I have a big issue with lots of QoL issues that Metaphor either has or lacks, so i can't imagine playing an older Atlus game which are even worse, sometimes, QoL issues is enough to steer me away from a game alone if there are either enough of them or bad enough. 1/11 STORY 🔲 Bad Story 🔲 Average 🔲 Good 🔲 Great ✅ FANTASTIC 2/11 GAMEPLAY 🔲 Lifeless/static 🔲 Poor 🔲 Average ✅ Good 🔲 Excellent 3/11 DIFFICULTY 🔲 Brain off 🔲 Relaxing ✅ Easy to learn / Hard to master 🔲 Difficult 🔲 Sekiro 4/11 GRIND 🔲 Nothing to grind ✅ Isn't necessary to progress 🔲 Average grind level 🔲 A lot of grind 🔲 Too much grind 5/11 GAME TIME / REPLAYABILITY 🔲 Short 🔲 Average ✅ Long 🔲 Near infinite 6/11 FIDELITY ✅ Low 🔲 Average 🔲 Good 🔲 Very Detailed 🔲 Near reality 7/11 ART STYLE/THEMATIC 🔲 Terrible 🔲 Good ✅ Beautiful 🔲 Cinematic 8/11 AUDIO/SOUNDTRACK 🔲 Earrape 🔲 Bad 🔲 Not too bad ✅ Good 🔲 Peak 9/11 PC REQUIREMENTS 🔲 Potato ✅ Low end 🔲 Medium end 🔲 High End 🔲 NASA 10/11 PRICE 🔲 Free 🔲 Wait for sale ✅ Worth the price 🔲 Best investment ever done 11/11 BUGS / CRASHES ✅ None that I can recount 🔲 Minor bugs/few crashes 🔲 Noticeable amount of bugs/Infrequent crashes 🔲 Filled with bugs/Frequent crashes 🔲 Complete mess

Overall, I really enjoyed Metaphor. It's not perfect, but it's one of Atlus' better titles in recent years. A lot of that is due to the narrative, though; I have a lot of complaints about the mechanics of the so-called '35th anniversary game'. On the surface, a lot of the plot in the game is very trite. "Humans are the real monsters". "Racism bad". These aren't exactly new tropes, especially in fantasy. But Metaphor doesn't pretend to have the answers, and they meld the tropes in a way that's fairly unique in my experience. It feels...genuine? I don't know if that's exactly the right word for what I mean, but it's the closest. Part of it, too, is Louis; he is probably the most compelling antagonist Atlus has written, and is probably my favourite JRPG antagonist as of writing. But it's not just surface level. The story plays with a *lot* of tropes in neat little ways. The music you hear is diegetic, which actually becomes a minor plot point; the fluffy animal character is also the grizzled veteran; the protagonist's parents [spoiler]are dead *but* they still guide him post-mortem along the way (even if that's not known even to him until the end). Similarly, the protagonist's initial visage looking like a 10 year old's first fantasy OC is because...it is.[/spoiler]. To an extent, it even uses and explains a Deus Ex Machina effectively. [spoiler]The player is the Deus Ex Machina.[/spoiler]. It's not perfect, though. It's inevitably going to draw parallels to Persona, and that's not completely invalid since it ultimately still follows the Fool's Journey (although it speedruns the section from The Tower onwards). There's a part in the story that was (IMO) *very obviously* cut content. And as much as I loved it as an Etrian Odyssey fan, the fourth act's reference is brazen. Like, I got spoiled on the setting's twist *listening to the soundtrack as the game downloaded because I recognised the song.* As soon as I descended the stairs, I brought up EO1's map of the floors and found them identical. (Well, mostly.) Hell, I even bypassed most of the dungeon in the same way you can in the original (albeit more easily due to it being an ARPG dodge-roll as opposed to a tough FOE fight). I know EO is Atlus' least-recognized JRPG series, and Re:Fantazio is their anniversary game so it had to have a reference somewhere, but I can think of several better ways to do it. As for mechanics, I'm conflicted. As I said above, I have complaints. But it's not all bad. I like Press Turn, and that's legitimately enough to make the combat fun for me. The Archetype system allows for some really neat (and potentially broken) combinations without being overbearing for those coming from easier Atlus titles like Persona. But I do have a *lot* of complaints. Firstly, a minor one is that a lot of the Archetypes feel like fodder for the four floating skills options you get, with no intentions on actually being used as a main Archetype. Atlus knows by now that physical weaknesses in Press Turn is a trap option, and yet they put them on several of them! However, my main complaint is that, even though this is allegedly Atlus' 35th anniversary game, the majority of the mechanics feel like Persona 5 + Press Turn, with every character getting the Wild Card but a significantly limited pool of Personas. Like, sure, you've got... [list] [*] Megami Tensei skill names [*] A skill system a la Digital Devil Saga [*] A front and back row system a la Etrian Odyssey (and some older SMT titles) [*] Archetypes that - at least superficially - reference other games. [/list] But the problem is that all of those are relatively inconsequential. Cool, fire spells are named 'Bot' instead of 'Agi', you made maybe fifteen people happy and made the rest of them think you randomly renamed some of them. I know I certainly did until someone informed me. Cool, you have a class system you can change on the fly. That's never been done before in the history of JRPGs. /s Cool, moving to the back row increases defense, and a couple Archetypes use the system. But there are *three spells* that meaningfully interact with it beyond moving everyone forward and backward, and only a single type of enemy (the chickens) care about it. The defense boost isn't substantial enough to really care, either,. (In EO, physical damage is halved *at the end of the calculation* if the target is in the back row.) And, to cap it all off, the one Archetype line that *really* uses it is one of the weakest in the game. Oh, speaking of: I'm not kidding about some Archetypes being 'superficial' references. Yes, the Gunner, Sniper, and Dragoon in EO all use either a gun or a bow. They're also, in order, *physical*-based elemental damage dealers, crit specialists/binders, and tanks. The Gunner line in Metaphor is none of these, albeit partly because the game doesn't have binds. At least it has ailment skills, but ailments aren't useful in Persona-style games for the player to use. At least the Masked Dancer and Summoner use inferences to create their items (with Dancer items referencing the Major Arcana and Summoner items referencing different demon Races), and they feature cameos of sorts...but most effects aren't unique. There also isn't really a tie to Soul Hacker's namesake beyond the name itself either AFAIK. Finally, there's difficulty options. I solemnly swear by the idea that you should balance around your hardest difficulty, and Atlus has a...schizophrenic history of doing that. Etrian Odyssey is nearly perfect in that regard, since the highest difficulty is always the intended experience, judging by the numbers behind the scenes. Nocturne's a good example of them *not* doing that, given Hard has a reputation of killing you several times in the tutorial fight. Now, I don't know what difficulty Metaphor was balanced around (the game's pretty easy beyond the optional bosses' insta-kill nonsense), but I *do* know that I want to throttle whoever decided the MAG costs for Archetypes should be doubled on the NG+ difficulty. Regicide also leans a lot heavier into a much more boring playstyle, and it's exclusively due to the 2x multiplier on Weak and Critical hits applied exclusively to your party. Sorry, I'm not taking an Archetype I can't hide the weakness of. Now, how would I change the game to improve it? I wouldn't necessarily do all of this, but... - Make buffs last until dispelled a la most SMT games - Add the three binds from EO, with the Gunner line now specialising in them. Probably also buff ailments in general for the player's benefit. - Add more area-of-effect options that hit only a row. This would interact interestingly with Press Turn's weakness system (since you could, for example, put someone Weak in the same row as someone who Repels a type, which is an interesting trade-off if the AI always targets weaknesses) - [strike]Bring back Smirking[/strike] TL;DR Basically Persona but with a more 'adult' narrative, like everyone thought it would be. References to other Atlus games are either superficial or audacious. Etrian Odyssey fans most affected,

I've never really klicked with the modern life-style of the Persona games, but always been intrigued by the concept. But this game.... oh, how we have klicked. This game is EXACTLY what I've been looking for. The game I never really knew I wanted. I truly adore the concept, setting, style, characters, combat, enemy design. The game is not afraid of being weird, while also addressing important subjects such as politics, inequality, racism, class and religion. Score: AMAZING/10

Reminiscent Of Persona. Honestly, I Would Highly Recommend It To Fans Of The Series, Such As Myself (Which Is Why I Got It In The First Place). Controls Are Smooth As Can Be, And Gameplay-Wise It Is On Par With The Very Best, Imo. Story 10/10 Music 10/10 But everything else... um........... This is the closest thing you'll get to Persona 6. (Or maybe this is Persona 6 in disguise?) However, ATLUS accidentally set an incredibly high standard with Persona 5, and in their effort to surpass it, they may have tried a bit too hard. The art style is... I don't know. The overuse of particle effects and poor anti-aliasing (or lack thereof at launch) makes the graphics more of a PM 2.5 on-screen. Instead of being visually captivating, the game ends up visually overwhelming. MP management is an issue throughout the game. Despite being set in a magical world (you can even see PM 2.5 on the screen, remember?), the game provides players with a frustratingly scarce amount of MP. While the first two or three towns are manageable, the fourth dungeon introduces an absurd difficulty spike. Grinding becomes unavoidable, but grinding requires MP—and without MP, combat is virtually impossible. To whoever designed that [spoiler]Dragongrace Shinjuku[/spoiler] dungeon, I hate you. This scarcity is compounded by: - The necessity to use MP for combat mechanics that rely on trial and error to identify enemy weaknesses. - High MP costs for essential skills. - No reliable way to replenish MP within dungeons. - All the genius enemy AI that will always "Critical" "Weakness" you. Or spam all the BS skills like "gained four turns icon" IDK, maybe the game wants you to save up all that precious MP and try to avoid unnecessary fights thus finding a way to the boss room as quickly as possible? This instead leaves you stuck in a dilemma: conserve MP and risk being under-leveled, or deplete resources and struggle to progress. [spoiler]The Dragongrace Shinjuku[/spoiler] dungeon is a prime example of poor design. Its maze-like layout is overly complicated, making navigation confusing and frustrating. Adding to the misery, the area is filled with an overwhelming number of monsters that seem disproportionately strong for the player's level at that stage. The combination of excessive encounters and disorienting design makes this dungeon one of the most unpleasant experiences in the game. (At the time of writing, only 47.5% of players able to clear this stupid dungeon) The game's economy is another pain point. Money is needed for weapons, armor, potions, and food, but earning enough is a hard. The game provided you an option to trade MAG for money but there’s NO option to exchange money for MAG (╯‵□′)╯︵┻━┻ , which is vital for leveling archetypes. When combined with the MP shortage issue and the game's time management mechanics. This leads to frustrations more than a challenge. Maybe we have to wait for Metaphor: ReFantazio Reloaded/Royal/Remaster/Re-fantasy edition of this game so that everything is better balanced. but as it stands, the game difficulty is a nightmare to play even on normal [b]Final Recommendation[/b] Save yourself the frustration and replay Persona 5 ([url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/pasathaioum5/recommended/1687950]the original, not the Royal edition[/url]). It’s a far more enjoyable experience. But if you really, really want to challenge yourself and have time and really love ATLUS's game, go ahead and enjoy. DO NOT read below If you haven’t played the game yet or haven’t finished it, [spoiler] The decision to set the game in a post-apocalyptic world, reminiscent of Horizon Zero Dawn and Xenoblade Chronicles, initially seemed like a promising story direction. However, the game fails to fully utilize this setting to it full extent - Why did it end? Just a war? - What caused it? Just anxiety? - Is there any way/possible to go back and live in the old world? - Is any important knowledge left behind? Just Elda's knowledge and some mural? - Why the old world is underground? And with full sky and water even) Instead, focusing only on the quest to defeat/stop the villain (That may also be a good thing, I guess) Still... that leaves the post-apocalyptic world setting feeling more like a surprise to the player rather than an integral part of the story. [/spoiler]

I tried. I love Persona 3, 4, and 5. I love RPGs. I love JRPGs. I just couldn't love this game. The story just isn't that good. It's painfully slow. With the main quest being something I don't care about doing. And as the story progresses, I still don't feel more inclined to do it. Some of the side quest stories are entertaining. The class system is cool. It's not all bad. The combat is essentially like all Atlus RPGs. I am not sure how this game won an award... It's just a lackluster political story :(

I hate hopes maybe a few hours into the game hoping it get good.... no it does not... IT DOES NOT! Its a dialogue push through snoozefest, being a therapist for these emotional NPCs, DISGUSTING diffusional 'classes', dungeons are "push forward to continue", graphics are ASS, and leveling is bonkers... Have the people EVEN PLAYED THIS GAME to make it game of the year choice???? You can't even grind. GAME PLAY SUCKS GRAPHICS SUCK CLASSES SUCK DUNGEONS SUCK BEING A THERAPIST FOR NPCs SUCK! GARBAGE!

This game is fresh, Atlus seems to take note with what fans liked and disliked from their games, then pour it to this game. There are no social link drags and fun to experiment with archetype builds. The drawbacks from this game, however, the ending felt quite flat after that story build-up, it was so good. Also, the RNG. Man, you can be extremely unlucky with the boss exploiting your weakness or/and debuffing you (their AI is pretty good), but it is not a problem since hit/evasion in this game is so busted. This game has replayability, I am currently on NG+ and trying to experiment with another build.
great rpg

(This review contains mild spoilers) - This game is really something else—ranging from the artwork, the UI/UX, characters, story, worldbuilding, soundtrack, gameplay, and bringing everything together into an incredible piece of art. I could talk about this game for days, but my most honest wish for you who might be reading this is: play it, give it a try, and beat it. If you are a fan of jRPGs or just RPGs in general, this game delivers it all, and it's one of those games that might change your perspective on some matters of life. The game delivers a strong and solid pacing and will always leave you wanting more or guessing what's going to happen when the next deadline of the calendar arrives. There are plenty of side quests to take part in and see the world grow into something alive. The battle system and overworld battle are fun and condense years of learning of what works and doesn't work in jRPGs—Metaphor's combat, leveling, gameplay, and quality of life systems are what every modern jRPG needs instead of clinging to traditional outdated designs (such as random unavoidable encounters). The soundtrack is excellent, and while I wish I could rate it as a "masterpiece," I cannot if I'm going to be honest. This game has some SERIOUS bangers on it (the battle theme is an obvious choice here), but at some point, the game keeps recycling some songs over and over, and I wish they invested in more variety to make some moments feel different. Shoji Meguro never disappoints in the quality of his work, though. The menus (UI/UX) of the game are on a whole other level. It's nothing new that Atlus delivers an incredible visual and gameplay-focused experience in this department, and Metaphor's UI is not an exception here. I've read some people saying the menus are convoluted, too busy, or confusing, but in my opinion, they are very much well-placed according to the game's motifs and themes—everything blends well together, every menu has a purpose and integrates into a piece of art that is there to afford a new look into the characters, their choices, and the world itself. They are fluid, easy to navigate, and visually pleasing. I will leave a critique here though—some quality of life features could be implemented, such as skipping archetype-acquiring scenes after you've seen them before, enabling the player to spend more than one Heroic Fruit/Leaf/Root for leveling an archetype at once, etc. The leveling and class system are wonderful and provide you with plenty of choices as you build your characters, however, it falls short near the endgame where you start unlocking the Royal Archetypes, making all previous archetypes just stepping stones to build extra skills on these "final" archetypes. I wish they found a way to keep classes interesting and make you choose different ones the same way they did throughout the majority of the game, where you had to switch and mix and match builds to adapt to enemies' weaknesses and tactics. After you get a Royal Archetype, there's no other choice—it's simply the best one you can have. Characters (main and supporting cast) are very well designed with different themes, with interesting personalities and intriguing backstories that develop further and further as you play the game. Some characters have really tragic events and story beats happening to them, for which I commend the writers for not backing down on some tough decisions, allowing for death to actually be lethal and permanent, for loss to be felt and mourned, for retribution to shine at its right moment, and so on. I really dislike when games kill someone just to bring that person back in a couple of minutes again, taking off all the pressure and the impact the scene had (this happens in the main quest once, but I can accept it in the context it happened). The world feels alive and interesting, most places have distinct visuals and themes for you to interact with, with lots of NPCs and side stories happening while they converge into the main quest motif. Not everything is perfect in this game though, the game has a few hiccups in some moments of the main story and suffers from one of the most severe lacks of interesting dungeon designs when we look at the side/optional dungeons. They are just empty corridors or mazes that stretch forever with little to no puzzles or other interesting vistas/rooms to interact with. This is what bothered me the most about this game—the main dungeons are very well dressed, designed, and they have a good amount of content, challenges, and interesting story or side-events happening. However, the side dungeons are just empty, with old ruins seemingly like they hire someone to clean them weekly because they don't even have skulls, cobwebs, dust or all sorts of stuff lying around telling a story about its past. The towers are just the same copy-pasted tower all over again, with a slight color variation. For a game with that much love poured into it, I feel like this department was really not interested in making these side parts of the game shine to their true potential. Really disappointing. The second point which deserves critique is the endgame story beats—don't get me wrong, the story itself is spectacular and very well written. However, by the end, it seems the writers of the dialogues lost their hand and hammered the same messages, values, and descriptions over and over on your head as a player to make sure you got it. Yes, we know about anxiety fueling Magla, yes, we understand that fear of the unknown fosters bad things in people and gives rise to despair, yes, we understand that near the final confrontation it's inevitable for friends and allies to reminisce about their hardships along the journey. They clearly overdid this, which is usually very present in jRPGs or other similar media, to the point I was like "Man, I love this game but please I don't want to see the characters taking rounds and talking about their emotions and hardships for 3-4 different scenes with the same message shoved in, get on with it." Alas, the final point which deserves critique is related to all confrontations against Louis. In general, I believe the game does a good job of making Louis an interesting villain and making you actually fight him in different stages of your (and his) strength. However, it does feel at a certain point the game is just using Louis as a carrot on a stick to keep you moving forward, maybe if they tuned down the number of confrontations against him to make them more impactful, that would be better. At some point, it just starts rubbing you in the wrong way where he's like "Ok see ya bozos, I'm running again but I will be waiting for you, AGAIN." Like, what the hell? We are here, man, let's just fight for real. It's artificial, it's uninspired. Really reminds me of the whole hook of FF7's cast pursuing the shadow and clues about Sephiroth and JENOVA all over again. Despite my critiques, I'm giving this game a 5/5 for everything it has presented and delivered—no game is ever without its flaws and that's what makes it a human piece of art. It certainly could be better, the lows are low and the strong points really shine through. Metaphor is really a strong entry into the jRPG universe and a marking in Atlus' history. It delivers an important message about themes related to mental health, faith, personal values, outlooks on life, politics, friendship, and the importance of being true to yourself, facing your inner challenges and emotions to channel the better version of you.

This game does a very poor job at onboarding people to this kind of games. Usually, I'm not attracted to that kind of art style and the "japanese way" of telling stories around battles. However, I liked what I saw at the game awards and in the trailers on steam, so I decided to give it a shot and hoped to maybe find a liking to this kind of games. Almost 2 hours into the prolog, the actual GAMEPLAY time was about 10-15 minutes max. The remaining 100 Minutes were dialogs and cut scenes that actually add very little to move the plot forward, 80% of it was mostly filler and repetition, diluting the actual plot, making it uninteresting. In addition, the fights have too many UI animations (mostly transition animations to go from one battle step to the next), which distracted from the important information of the UI. Maybe something I might have gotten used to, I don't know, but it matches the game's constant use of transition overlays between dialog sequences. The whole UI experience seems to suffer from ADHD. I'm not saying that this is a bad game in total, but it has a terrible tutorial and onboarding experience and definitely doesn't help to make the genre accessible to people who aren't already fond of it.

[h1]Fun Yet Non-Final Fantasy[/h1] [b]TLDR:[/b] Fun for Atlus RPG fans, but has some serious problems and utterly screams [i]"We are pushing out a Plus Edition within two years"[/i] on several points. Buy it if you catch it on sale, otherwise you're probably safe to wait to not have to buy it 'twice' for the content. [h2]Pro's in short:[/h2] [list] [*]Press Turn System from Shin Megami Tensei is superior to One More System from Persona, I will die on this hill. [*]Fans of Persona 5's presentation will eat well. Art style is very 'Aura Battler Dunbine' mixed with 'Nadia: The Secret of Blue Water' with a good chunk of worldbuilding. [*]Followers/Social Links no longer require a Guide to progress, they do so automatically so long as you have enough Virtues/story progression. Correct dialogue choices only give bonuses to MAG/secondary currency. [*]Archetypes allow for full customization of every party member's playstyle to a point, and allow for more on-the-fly mix-and-match tactics for teambuilding to prepare for challenges. No need to find a Fusion Calculator! [*]Gallica is cute. [/list] [h2]Con's in short:[/h2] [*]You will drown in dialogue, the game is extremely text-heavy as the game loves to Tell and not Show. Majority of Followers/Social Links are not voiced either. On a plus side, the Protagonist CAN talk at last, but usually gets everyone else to dialogue for him outside of choices so why bother? [*]Real Time Battle is very droll and kind of clunky, especially around Magla Crystal Spawners come the midgame. It's just swing and a dodge-roll, nothing remotely in-depth, and some animations will get you slapped by a skeleton sliding half a mile across the floor. [*]There's a lot of reused assets here. Non-major dungeons and a good chunk of enemies will be seeing pallete-swaps. Some more than once. [*]The music is mid. The tracks with chanting give those good Strange Journey vibes and the main battle theme gives the game a distinct identity, but most other tracks are forgettable. Meguro's still good but it feels like the fantasy genre is holding him back in a way. Also the Human Boss theme is just bad/boring. [*]Follower ranks form a nasty chokepoint on Archetypes rather quickly in terms of Inheritance slots or upgrades. The game also really likes to try to force you into picking up Magic early on due to mission structures if you want any skill slots, and not allowing you to get a dedicated/good Magic party member until the [spoiler]FIFTH[/spoiler] teammate joins. [*]There are some performance issues, particularly regarding the Gauntlet Runner or Brilehaven at times. Thankfully the battle sequences don't seem to suffer from it but weaker PCs might have some trouble. [*]The game will get awful preachy about politics, and that's an integral part of the game. I personally didn't mind it, hell I liked it, but it's about as un-subtle as a hammer on an anvil at times. Some folks might not like that sort of thing, so fair warning. As an aside, I feel like the game didn't go far enough in regards to some topics and themes especially early on... [*]Archetypes are janky when it is time to switch. Any time you switch Archetypes in the menu, you will be forced to switch out their gear, which means you have to tediously go back and switch out every single piece of equipment one by one. Did I mention that some gear types outside of the weapons are locked to specific Archetypes? It would have been nice to have a 'save this kit for this Archetype' function instead of forcing them to just slap on whatever has the highest Attack/Defense blindly. [*]Gallica will simply [i]NOT SHUT UP[/i] during Squad Battle. Gods help you if you have a debuff or someone has more than a paper cut's worth of damage, because she will pipe up about it EVERY SINGLE TURN. In fact, no, ALL of your party members will constantly fret and freak out on the field if you walk around with more than 10% of your health gone for more than five seconds. It gets very annoying since apparently THOSE are the voiced quotes but not any of the quest-relevant chatter? [/list] [h2]The BIG Con:[/h2] Anyone who's played the game to completion can freely read but a single word here: [spoiler]Altabury.[/spoiler] For those who hadn't but want a cliffnotes version without spoilers, the game basically dances around AT LEAST two specific points where story dungeons were clearly cut from the game to get a release out. It's pretty egregious because they will give you the boss fights 'outside' of those locations but skimp out on the buildup. They also manage to pull this sort of stunt twice in a row in quick succession which left a bad taste in my mouth. The first half of the game starts off rather strong and then someone just snapped the brake line in the second half in an effort to hit the finish faster. It very much felt like those sections in particular are meant to be what the usual [i]Atlus Re-Release With New Heroine Duct Taped On Top[/i] stunt is supposed to patch in, and I'm a little tired of it at this point. It's for that particular last reason that I can say this: If you like Atlus RPGs, you'll love this, but please only try to buy this when it's on sale at most. I'd be shocked if they don't try to push out a new version before 2026 with a bunch of extra content on. I give it three Decarabia out of five. Good game but, again, feels like it's not complete....

I just closed the game from having beaten it. The short version is that this is a great game. The longer version is kind of hard to put into words. There are so many things about this game that are odd and weird, but not in a bad way. Down to the very battle theme, things are very unexpected. And I usually don't like the air quotes, "deep" games that get into metaphysical concepts. Like the differences between what is fantasy and what is reality, but just a little bit of suspension of disbelieve really goes a long way for this game. It allows you to really get into the world-building and character development on offer, which I can't overstate how great it is. I'm the kind of guy who never really talks to NPCs or will even flip through some dialog if I feel like I "get the point." But I found myself engaged and interested than usual, which should speak volumes alone. I'm a pretty big fan of the SMT series and have been ever since Nocturne. And I say this because I actually don't like the Persona series. I bring this up because I feel there's probably a small subset of Megaten fans in the same boat. It's pretty clear that there are a lot of Persona elements in the game, from the time progression to the social aspect of raising level with followers. But Metaphor actually seems to pick mechanics, themes, and systems from across the franchise. And I'm glad to say that this did not impact my enjoyment of the game. I was far more interested in emboldening my allies towards the greater cause than I ever was trying to get Ann Takamaki to go on a date with me. While the system, in theory, isn't much different, just losing the skin of a slice-of-life high schooler completely fixed this for me. And I'd hate someone missing out because they had the same concerns and passed on this. The game, though, isn't without some of it's issues. The thing that bugged me the most is (and this may be considered a spoiler by some people, so fair warning) towards the end of the game, you will unlock special archetypes unique to each character. But those characters have to have trained in many other archetypes to unlock. If throughout the playthrough, you didn't focus the right set of archetypes, you are very likely not going to be able to experience these as having to train up multiple archetypes from square one is just not feasible. Specially considering most of the prerequisite classes require OTHER archetypes be leveled as well. It feels punishing for not being able to see the future. But other than a few other nit-picks not really even worth mentioning, the game is a great experience and I can see why it was nominated for game of the year.

Beyond doubt, this is the real Game of the Year for me. I love all of the followers and the relationships you build with them. Heck, I even like a few I really shouldn't, but oh well! The writing is very well done overall, and while yes, there are a few tropes, there are also plenty of twists to keep me intrigued. The art style, including or perhaps especially the menus, is amazing. I love how it takes Persona, adds in some Shin Megami Tensei, and comes out with something better than either. Having a Persona-esque game in a fantasy setting is wonderful for me. The archetypes do have a bit of repetitiveness, but each tier of the various archetypes has its own strengths. Absolutely amazing game!

Solid MMO. It’s been ages since I’ve actually enjoyed one, and this game gets a lot right. The real fun begins at level cap. Everything before that is just onboarding. The negative reviews are hilarious. People with 200-400 hours already whining about daily dungeon limits? Touch some grass. The game’s been out for a month. Step back, breathe, and maybe turn off the PC for a bit. Also, those limits people complain about? They’re actually great for combating bots and keeping the economy in check. Even with them, there’s plenty to do. PvP, world bosses, exploring, fishing, this game isn’t short on content. If you're that desperate to grind you can always grind the open world with no limits whatsoever. Cheers!

I had High Hopes for this game upon the 1 October release. However after slightly over 2-months of fairly sustained gameplay, I have now (along with most of my guild and alliance) quit this game. I am a big fan of PVP gameplay in MMORPG games and have played almost every MMORPG since 2002. While T&L looked very promising for its PVP gameplay, it soon became apparent that unless your whole guild had low ping, all players turned up for every fight, and ran auto-block macros. You would not be able to compete with the other guilds from mega-alliances which will bring players in in the last minute to fill their roster, so they are always fighting with 70 players. Furthermore, if you are a Kiwi or Australian - I would NOT recommend this game as the ping is average at best, even with the use of ExitLag, and the Boonstone/Riftstone fights are very late for us (1am for Kiwis) and therefore not realistic. Plus the Maintenance of this game, makes the game unplayable every Thursday during our prime-time. Pros: - The graphics in this game are stunning! The game is visually beautiful. - Boonstone/Riftstone PVP fights can be really fun if you have a good guild to play with. - The Main Story Quest storyline was quite interesting and impressive. Cons: - Game may not be Pay to Win, but it is definitely pay-to-save-a-boat-load-of-time. - Botting and Players using Macros are rampant (and very obvious) in this game. - The Dev's dont appear to care about players cheating at all. - Mega Alliances and Hand-Holding make most of the open-world Boss content rather boring. - For Aussies and Kiwis, dont expect to play the game on Thursdays during prime-time as this is when the global maintenance happens. - The Oceanic servers are based in Asia, not Oceania - therefore the ping for Oceanic players is terrible.

I will begin with I loved this game. But unfortunately: 1. It became unenjoyable for me ever since last update (Runes Update) You have to keep grinding multiple runs in just for a chance to level up the runes you have and it's all randomized. I'm not saying 1 or 2 runs, 10 or 20 runs What I'm talking about you need hundreds and hundreds of run to maximize your runes. 2. It feels stupid you separated normal 2-star dungeon tokens and dimensional trials. You get 900 tokens a day, 450 tokens per run, so total 2 runs daily then what? I have to go back grinding dimensional trials for runes again. Why won't you make it so that we can open chest at the end of dimensional trial?????????? 3. It feels retarded that you changed weekly dungeon mission. first tier: 4500 token spent second tier: 10 dimensional trial runs third tier: 15 dimensional trial runs totalling between 35 to 50 dungeon runs a week! WE ARE NOT CORPORATE SLAVES! i know some of you will say "you can farm runes by doing field bosses and dynamic events" yeah you tell me how many hundreds of times you have to do that to maximize your gear? My suggestions: 1. Make it so that we can spend our tokens at the end of dimensional trial runs, put the chest in there! 2. Bring back old dungeon weekly mission, so we are not forced to grind and still get max rewards! TL;DR Many of your spenders come from working class, don't make our lives harder! We lack time! We simply want to have some fun! Have a good day!

An okay MMO - As a casual MMO enjoyer this was a lot easier to get into than FFXIV or WoW. But, the lack of servers for AU/NZ players has ruined the experience. Dying to a dungeon boss due to desync, getting yeeted into oblivion from any grappling hook or losing a fight from lag is a terrible experience. Outside of the APAC region it's most likely more enjoyable without the server issue.

Good MMO but it's your typical Korean MMORPG. You either pay up with boundless amounts of time, or you open up your wallet. Currently, the endgame is the PvP and in its current incarnation I can't really recommend it. The developers have over-emphasized AOE abilities, making large fights monochromatic. Player survivability is abysmal. Moreover, Arena combat plays completely differently(because it's 3v3 only) so you're forced to have separate equipment sets. You're forced to have a separate set to efficiently farm PvE, this means you have at least 3 sets if you choose to engage in all content efficiently. You need even more if you're looking to use different weapon combos. Of course, you get a few equipment presets for free but if you want more, you must pay. That pretty much sums up the whole game. The game is free, however, so if you're looking just to explore PvE content in a group, I can recommend it for that.

I really fell into this game at launch but waited to make my review. It has some amazing moments, great msq, guild system, etc. But after putting in the time I saw the cracks. It's a PVP game period, which wouldn't be a bad thing except unless you are going to focus on PVP in endgame there really is no purpose. There is a lot of antics going on with certain guild alliances taking over all the servers, so unless you are affiliated with those guilds it's pointless. This is not a game for casual PVE focused or mild PVP players, you will get stomped. The community has some good in it, but I encountered much toxic behavior in world chat, which ruins it for me. I gave it a go but quickly realized this game will not hold up for long unless some changes are made. It does not have a long shelf life. So if you looking to invest your time into a game long term, do not play this. This is a flash in the pan, niche bro-fest that will destroy itself quickly. Thanks Amazon Games for once again proving yourself as out of touch with what an MMORP is...

So I have played over 500 hours and I got to say I would not recommend this game. I've had fun for a bit but it is riddled with flaws. The combat is fun but extremely unbalanced with CC chains you can't break out with that is quickly followed by damage combos that nuke you (and I am geared). The community is extremely toxic and leaves a sour taste in your mouth as the same no lifers hop from one MMO to another ruining each game they touch. We have one guild actively attempting to 'kill' the serve, recruiting all talent from small guilds (nuking alliances), harassing player into quitting the game and not to mention scripting and boosting through third party. The devs need to dive into these bigger guilds and ban these players if they want the game to last past the summer. I'll be playing until next siege, if the server dynamic does not change I'll like quit.

(lucent is ingame currency that you can pay for with real money, you can use it to buy items off marketplace or itemshop) After some time invested i can clearly say that this game is totaly guild orientated. All yo do is hit lvl 50 via quest and before you join guild you can do only dungeons, open dungeons and world bosses also some openworld events but all of these is limited somehow how ever if you join guild this thing changes. You get additional "world bosses" that you can kill weekly with your guys, you can fight for some terrains on map and here the real problem begins. If you want to join guild like this you need to join startign guild or pay lucent to level your gear fast because no matter how good you are in this game, 70% is weapon combo that you have choosen and gear you are wearing. If you somehow get to play with hardcore pvp guild you are obligated to play almost as part time job because if you missed at least 1 guild event and have no time to message on discord or somehow, you are going to get kicked from the guild. But lets say something more about guilds directly. So main purpose of being in guild is to attend to these guild activities wherte you fight for some terrain on the map but for yourself you do it mainly to get lucent to grow in game faster or to drop items from bosses, but in reality you mostlikely will not get any items from your guild because, these items are limited by number of bosses you can kill weakly and distribution of these items is BY GUILD OWNERS so yes they decide that who get the item. even if you drop it they can take it for themselves but if you are kind a believer you can wait until owners and their frinds feed enough and MAYBE they will give you something but not necessarerly because they can also sell this items on marketplace directly and get lucent... :). Ok but what if you have a job? Like real life one? If you do shifts you are going to miss 95% OF ALL THE EVENTS in game because most important events are scheduled between 18-22 (6pm-10pm) and ofcourse if you miss them you are not getting anything. But ok lets assume that you have pack of great frinds and all is ok and you created guild with them, you grow and grow, and finaly join some battles for control over some area and you loose, well you wont get anything for participation in it but that not a problem because it takes time to get better but soon you notice one thing, leaderboards of guild. Yes you look there and see that almost whole map is controlles by one guild but how? Game prevents you from doing more than 1 battle at the time. Well you see, it does prevent you from this but not from creating 2nd the same guild with one letter changed in it and youcreate huge guild because you add it to you friendly list ant that way you create instead of 70ppl max capatity guild emmmm 280ppl capacity guild. and this you will face on the worlbosses which are main thing to drop best in slot items for you build, and ofcourse the system which rewards you is totaly at their side because there is so called contribution which generally speaking do... if you and your guild kill the most of other people arpound they gain contribution over the boss and their chances are increasing BUT people who die or guilds that are loosing to this huge guild alliance THEY are loosing their contribution so besically you are loosing more and more chance to drop ANYTHING from the boss. It's so called gate keep. OK but lets talk about solo content in game: there is no such a content, you cannot grind alone and even if you are strong enouggh (for example call shadowmancer can do it) you are still limited by tokens that allows you to kill mobs xDDDD. Closed dungeons are trash they are boring and repetitive chances for items are drasticly low so most of regular players will have to do it multipletimes. So dont take vacation at work just to do it because its also limited per day. There is a pity system but to grind eanything this way well.. it takes like 8 days to get one item which. Last thing is about gear well, if you drop something this item recives some trait (additional stat) and this traits are randomized from 8 avaiable its quite fair because you mostly get most important ones so here its ok but the thing is, each item can upgrade one trait max 3 times so if you got like trait that gives you 150HP you can upgrade it to 600HP. You can have 3 different traits in one item and here last problem begins, to place another trait either you have to drop EXACTLY the same item but with different trait and combine them or use special stones to unlock this traits AND of course these stones are locked behing paywall and grind in the same time because you can get them only from litograph book (this is like book where you put different items and you get some better items) or you can buy season pass to get this. There is one more method you can craft them at any merchant but to do it you need to use pity tokens that you can use to craft your most wanted gear so.... I quit this game because there is nothing for people that want to have fun of playing because all of PVP and guild system is connected with stressing and grinding everyday.

There are too many issues with the game. With heat, armor moves, rage art and an insane amount of jailing followed up by 50-50's, the game, like many others are saying, feels like an online gambling casino. Offensive power and reversals are too overwhelming in this game. After some patches it is a bit better, bit still far from balanced. You are not free to express your own play style anymore, just forced to play like everyone else, aggressive, aggressive and aggressive. It is possible to close the round in 1 hit, followed by a combo, wall carry and wall combo and then 1-2 wrong guesses for the defender. The monetization and costumization is terrible, with passes full of useless stuff and a arcade avatar mode no one asked for. Speaking of things no one asked for... Heihachi was a questionable character to have him back, like Jun, but it is still kinda okay I guess since the Tekken story had always been whack. But Clive... Ok look, I'm not wishing for Tifa, never cared much for that but... this guy is so lost on his way to Soul Calibur he is angry and decided to pick a fight with every Tekken character trying to help him find the way to the right game. SE most likely trying to push people to up the sales for the failed FF16, but this is going to ruin Tekken like how Akuma and Noctis ruined T7. Tekken took too many L's, maybe it is for the best to leave it alone for now.

Completely blown away. I first started playing Tekken 3 when I was 6 years old or so and I loved it. I got Tekken 7 and really enjoyed it too but when Tekken 8 was announced I knew it was gonna be amazing. I pre ordered it and its hands down the best purchase I've ever made. I immediately became addicted. The graphics, the gameplay, the mechanics, the music, everything is beautiful. The heat system is by far my favorite fighting game mechanic ever. I love the various things you can do with it like combo extensions and just smashing people to pieces. I hear complaints about the battle pass and such but I just ignore it I'm not interested so it doesn't bother me. Like you don't have to pay for the stuff if you don't like it? Also the people complaining about spamming and such have never blocked or used a power crush in their lives. If you're losing to spam that's on you. The best fighting game and it would be an absolute crime if it doesn't win Fighting Game of the Year. Namco truly outdid themselves. Up there with Tekken 3 and Tekken 5 for best Tekken games period.

"After reaching Garyu in Tekken 8, I found my calling: the art of unhinged combat. Button-mashing wasn't enough—I needed to become Tekken. I quit my job, sold my bed, and turned my living room into a full-scale training room. My days consist of punching brick walls and yelling 'Dorya!' at pigeons, while perfecting wave dashing and Korean backdashing in real life. Within days, I was wave dashing through intersections, dodging cars like poorly timed jabs. By week two, I was backstepping out of awkward conversations. My landlord asked about my strange footwork in the hallway; I responded with a sliding roundhouse kick and claimed 'frame advantage.' By month one, I was banned from every mall in the area for crouch-dashing into fountain displays and 'intimidating mannequins.' I now backdash during conversations and wave dash to the fridge. The Iron Fist Tournament is my destiny. If you can't win with skill, win with style. No regrets—only restraining orders and Perfects."

I don't usually write reviews, however with the current state of the Tekken Community review bombing the game; I wanna counter that. So if you aren't aware this game had suffered to review bombing twice already now. Once during TGU and together with the game not giving a dlc map for free. Things to take note this is my first officially own Tekken game, I know for a fact that dlc maps are paid before hand. And the fine print on Tekken 8 did not mention including any maps for free yet people get upset. I read them. TGU however is quite dumb for the Tekken Team for disqualifying players that got in the tournament despite their regions not being allowed to participate. So yah I understand that backlash. However as of right now I just think it's stupid of people complaining about the new DLC character Clive and then review bombing the game again; people like to complain about this game too much despite them saying "I'm not gonna play the game anymore", " The game isn't balance", "this isn't tekken anymore". Here's what I have to say, the game is great nonetheless of the negativity that this game receives there is a constant player base that never stops playing it. That includes me. More than that the game continue to improve itself little by little. The balancing could be tweak more yes but balances shouldn't be rush. And the last major balance update this game had made things fairly great. It's not perfect however they are trying. As I've said little steps. Anyway I think I'm getting over my self. What I'm trying to say is this game is fun. Nonetheless what people say or like to complain about. For all the people who keeps complaining you can go somewhere else; we don't want you here. This is the best Tekken game so far. I wanna applaud the Tekken 8 team for not giving up for admitting there mistakes and even trying to compensate the players for said mistakes. I wan't to let the Tekken 8 Team, Harada, Murray, know that despite all the negativity people throw at them that I am here and its players supporting them. I know there are more good things to come and this game would just get better over time.

Gameplay Mechanics: 9/10 Narrative: 7/10 Graphics: 8/10 Sound and Music: 9/10 Replayability: 10/10 Innovation: 8/10 Civilization VI builds upon the iconic turn-based strategy formula the series is known for, offering a fresh and vibrant experience with new mechanics that enhance depth and variety. As the leader of a civilization, players guide their people from the ancient era to the modern age, competing through culture, science, domination, or diplomacy. With its colorful presentation and smart systems, Civ VI delivers one of the most engaging strategy experiences to date. The gameplay mechanics are excellent, with major innovations like the District System, which requires players to carefully plan cities by placing specialized districts on the map for optimal growth. This adds a new layer of strategy to city-building and forces players to think ahead about space and resources. The addition of Eureka Moments for research, Governors, and Loyalty systems further deepens gameplay. While there’s a learning curve to managing these mechanics, they make each decision feel impactful and rewarding. Gameplay earns a solid 9/10. The narrative is largely emergent, driven by the player’s choices and the rise and fall of civilizations throughout the ages. While it lacks a structured story, the sandbox experience allows players to craft their own alternate histories. Competing leaders with their unique agendas add personality to the campaign, but the storytelling remains secondary. Narrative earns a 7/10. Visually, Civ VI adopts a bright and stylized aesthetic that distinguishes it from its predecessors. While some players may prefer more realistic visuals, the art style is clean, charming, and easy to navigate. The detailed animations for leaders and units bring life to the world, earning graphics an 8/10. The sound and music are outstanding, with each civilization receiving its own theme that evolves as the ages progress. The soundtrack is beautifully composed, and the atmospheric sound effects—whether from bustling cities or battles—add immersion to the experience. This dimension scores a strong 9/10. Replayability is where Civilization VI truly excels. With countless civilizations to choose from, procedurally generated maps, and various victory conditions, no two games feel the same. Expansions like Rise and Fall and Gathering Storm further enrich the experience with new mechanics like Loyalty, natural disasters, and diplomatic victories. Replayability earns a perfect 10/10. Innovation is strong, with the District System, new victory conditions, and expanded diplomacy providing meaningful changes to the core formula. While Civ VI builds on the foundation of its predecessors, these additions add enough freshness to keep it engaging. Innovation scores an 8/10. In summary, Civilization VI is a standout entry in the legendary series, combining deep strategy with a visually appealing and highly replayable experience. The introduction of districts and new mechanics adds a fresh layer of challenge, while the vibrant presentation and excellent music make it a joy to play. Whether you’re a longtime fan or new to the series, Civ VI offers a compelling and endlessly replayable journey through history.

It is a great strategy game that allows you to take your time to make decisions. The Civ VI version of the game has quite a bit more complexity versus earlier versions making the strategy more fun. The game also allows many different paths to victory which really gives you multiple ways to enjoy the game.

If strategy games are your thing, then Sid Meier's Civilization VI is an absolute phenomena. The game is a perfect cocktail of strategy, historical depth and imagination. You have to lead a civilization throughout the ages. From how to win a war, to how to progress science or culture; the strategic options are limitless. The stand out feature of CIV VI has to be the number of different ways to play the game. If you are an expansionist militarist, or a peaceful builder who won in a culture-dominated race, or even a diplomatic strategist – there is a route for you. Every civ has its own capabilities and units which makes every approach unique. The graphics is great, with a new bright and colourful style compared to old versions. The likeliness of the world is astonishing because the maps are very artistic, and the cities are teeming with life. At certain levels, it becomes easy to forget the world you are in as you concentrate on the details of your cities, armies and various wonders you have built. The new district system is also a fun twist, as it makes planning how a city will look and function a more entertaining part of the game. It is interesting to consider how to organize areas such as science or entertainment centers in order for them to function properly which adds another level when taking care of the city. The only bad thing I can think of is that the game can at some points be badly intimidating and feel overwhelming for new players. You have to learn the game in order to enjoy it, just like other strategy games like Hearts of Iron or Europa Universalis.

Bought it to play with family. I despise this thing. In Civilization 4, you had information. A city would tell you how much of each resource it was producing, where the production was coming from, what bonuses were in play, what the bonuses were. If there were penalties, that was explicit. The cost of performing an action with a unit was viewable in advance so you could plan for it. The benefit of performing an action was explicit. The benefit of engaging in diplomacy with the AI was clear. In Civilization 6, none of that information is presented to the player, and if you actively search for it, it's impossible to find. Costs are given in turns to completion instead of hard numbers, which makes any progression practically invisible. Terrain improvement is terribly curtailed and unit movement is an absolute joke. Any feel of the map, the world, and my place in it, is a complete writeoff. Everything I hated about Beyond Earth is still here. If Civ 7 isn't a complete rollback, I truly hope the studio folds in on itself.

Mixed review: The game will be excellent after some months, it's already pretty fun in most parts. Probably after EA it will be way better. Right now GGG is really experimenting and trying stuff. If you want to try the campaign, it will probably get better later and it will have more Acts, because right now it's Act 1-3 with a "new game+" to get you leveled enough for maps. Maps are known as "waystones" here and it clearly is not the final idea for endgame. There are very OP stuff being abused and breaking the economy. You may not care for economy, but Solo Self Found is horrible right now. There is 0 deterministic crafting which is very difficult for SSF players. Rolling is almost useless in the endgame, so the "souls-like" experience is only for campaign. The build diversity is very lacking, if you build armor/life you are basically handicapped and the skill gems restrictions makes stats stacking the only viable option to test more skill combinations. There are many, really many balance problems. One-hit kill and on death mechanics gets crazy in end-game. I've stopped after doing my quota of Tier 15 maps and deciding that it's better to wait.

TL;DR: There are issues on the horizon with the game's soulslike systems and endgame, and it'll come down to GGG admitting their ideas don't work and changing direction, or doubling down on their 'vision', a vision that has a very niche appeal. It's tough to review half a game, but that's kind of where we are right now. As it stands, the game is fine from the perspective of the experience from act 1-3 on both difficulties, but there are major issues that have to be addressed with endgame and looming issues with some of the games core systems. To save a bunch of words, the current endgame is best described as 'Hardcore mode light' and requires a very different play style than what was required in the first section of the game. Even if it's a placeholder endgame, its not acceptable game design in a world where Diablo 4 exists. One shot to clear a map, XP death penalties, a downgrade of gear on subsequent attempts to clear maps, and the fact you are at the mercy of RNG to get the items that even let you attempt to clear maps beyond tier 1. Its a game killer, and they need to address it. This leads into the other half of issues. To be short, they Souls'd it up, and didn't balance it properly. High damage/insta-kill attacks with barely visible telegraphs due to the games dark aesthetic. The dodge mechanic was borderline useless until they changed it (warning: temporarily, so they could come back and make it bad again), and their change made half the bosses and mechanics in the game trivial. Movement speed bonuses turn some of their new mechanics into complete jokes. The 'best' builds are once again turning out to be minion/pet builds because you can let your pets play the game while you hide safely around a corner, meaning the 'best' way to play the game is to not play the game and let the game play itself. The most concerning thing, to me, is that the half the classes aren't enabled yet and it become clear why if you know where to look. Most of the missing classes are melee focused, and melee doesn't work/ The new game systems were not designed with melee combat in mind. The Trial of Ascendancies honor system is the clearest example of that.

Welcome to the new enchanted game - Path of Stormweavers! In this exciting new game you have so many choices and paths to take to become the hero of your dreams! You can either be a mighty plebeian worm of various chunks and splatters or a divine weaver of storms! A difficult choice no doubt! This land can be dangerous though, so make sure to stack your energy shields into the stratosphere, becoming impervious to almost any attack! No need for functionally useless stats like armour, evasion, or resistance! They’ve proven to be mathematically useless by our archmage researchers. Some may tell you that the key to survival is to engage with the environment and its denizens, to learn their ways and predict their next moves - do not be fooled my dear weavers of cheese! Those cog headed fools are delirious, as you only get one shot at anything in this land so it is best not to risk your time with anything but the most cheddary thick strategies. You must functionally break the world and weave a destiny devoid of any interaction with anything except your right mouse button. Do not be fooled by the numerous weapons that drop, the staves and wands are our saviours as toiling in the close combat techniques is for the weak minded who wish to die to post death seppuku monsters. Avoid your robes being scuffed by staying a screen or two away from any enemy that dares to be hostile. If you see or smell them you’ve failed my dear sorceresses! While you’re one tapping the big bad bosses with lightning conduits and orbs of storm with your shockingly stylish gear make sure to avoid using any items that do not increase the fatty boons of loot - you will be one of the only classes that can afford to use any! 100, 200, 300, 400, 500 we can’t get enough!! The sweet divine clangs of dopamine will be yours if only you embrace the greed of the storms! This is not a race to greatness my friends…no, this is a casual sail down the rivers of the great material continuum, the gambling simulator that will define the genres of time itself! You can take that extra time you’ve saved by avoiding grinding like a coal miner to consult with the mighty trading oracles provided to us by the gods - outside of the game reality of course, trading in house would be far too convenient. Post your ludicrously over priced goods on the defunct market of randomness, potentially price fix items at your pleasure, or just link your stash tabs to show off with no intention of selling - as you are the masters of this divine foreign land as well! You may have almost no use for divine orbs, but a fatty stack of them makes a perfect nest for you to sleep atop and snuggle with like the wifu you deserve. (lvl 90 witchhunter who has hit the wall, T15+) Joking aside, it is an amazing game, but it obviously needs balancing work desperately.

For an Early Access game, this is already super polished and filled with enough content to get you through for a while until they roll out the rest of the classes and/or release the full game. This was basically what I wanted and expected from the Diablo franchise. All that being said, it's certainly not yet perfect. There are still bugs and kinks they need to fix and, not to mention, I'm not the biggest fan of the pay-for-early-access business model for a game that's intended to be free to play on release. It's like we're paying the devs to test their game and give feedback on the bugs and issues. It would have made more sense to do it the other way around and have the game f2p in EA to get people's feet in the door and have that reasonable asking price on full release. I'd gladly pay by then. But other than the small gripe I have, I'd definitely still recommend this game for ARPG fans or those that just want a challenging game with so much class building potential.

It's everything I remember being good about the original, but the combat feels much more engaging. It's not like Diablo or any other ARPG I've played, it feels more like a MOBA control scheme (if you've enjoyed those you'll find a similar ebb and flow through combat). Graphically more impressive than the original as well, though various systems seem to have changed. Fear not! The MASSIVE passive skill tree is still present and still feels impactful. My first character is a a monk and being able to markedly increase his evasion, shield and life gain on kills has made his sustain admirable, and I'm just now starting to focus on damage. Other characters I've played less but have found their trees to be equally engaging. This is a "pay to get in" early access period, so many things will change. You are essentially just buying their microtransaction currency though, as you are provided with it to use immediately. So paid "beta" yes, but it's fair and it's the same model they used during their early access period with the first game. What I've experienced here is already on par with what I enjoyed about Diablo IV last year. With improvements to come, I think this is another case of PoE being the better game over the more established IP, but that remains to be seen. Whatever the case, I think it's worth your buck if you can't wait for full release. If you don't enjoy supporting these endeavors (or early access/kickstarter/etc) and want to wait, feel free. That's my two cents.

I didn't play POE 1 but I did hear it was good. My first real ARPG was D4, and Last Epoch followed so I don't have much experience and I can't compare too much. The game feels great while you're doing the campaign. Difficult but not too much, we can't say it's a "try-hard" but you'll need to die and repeat for some parts. I didn't check how much time I took to finish that first part but I would say smth like 30 - 35 hours. When you finish the campaign for the first time, begins the "cruel" version of this exact, same campaign. This begins to feel like devs had some lack of inspiration but ok, it's EA, I'll do it because I want to know what endgame feels like. This second run has nothing more to offer me. No challenge at all, I'm running through maps I already know without dying, even for a solo player but hey, honestly I followed some build on Maxroll, so maybe it's just as it is. Bosses melt, so I begin to feel that my character is beefed up. Great, even if it's already beginning to feel boring. When I finally finished the campaign the second time I was lvl 60+ I think. Great, now begins the endgame I was looking for. Except nothing is explained to you. You have to ask other players to understand what you have to do. There's one quest left: Finish 10 "tier 1" maps. Not so difficult, I looted the waystones in the 3rd Act, cruel, of the campaign. Some maps can be tedious, some "challenges" (altars, in my case) were hell, honestly: I'm playing which, infernalist with some minions, so I'm a little squeechy, I know, but sometime I'm just dying without the time to react (because, you know, you're blocked by some enemy/map item while trying to leave some dangerous zone...). And when you die in Endgame, you lose the map, the "key", the loot. You're just back the base, and you need to try again, from the beginning. But yeah, still motivated to see what the game still have to offer. So you make the 10 "tier 1" maps, and you got 2 Atlas points, that you can use to get some more Waystones. Okay... Now you have to do 10x "tier 2" maps, which I did. Loot just feels unrewarding (honestly it has already been the case for some time, but at this point you just begin to feel it drastically) at this point, you don't loot good items, you don't loot many waystones, and you don't loot the currencies you need to upgrade the stuff you have. So you begin to die more often. Now I have to do 10x "tier 3" maps. Okay, so now it's just my ******* job. Clear some maps, to maybe find some key to open other maps, to maybe after the 100 map I clean, find some upgrade I can't "craft" because I lack the currency. So yeah, the game is good for like 35 - 40 hours, which is not this bad honestly but after that it's just a job. I feel like I just lost my time because I just don't want to open the game to make the same thing, again and again. I do understand it's EA, but still, it's just boring.
